questions.text: Which of the following is the common cause for diarrhea and dehydration in children:
questions.solution:
The symptoms of watery diarrhoea, vomiting, and fever, especially in a young child, strongly suggest rotavirus infection, a leading cause of pediatric gastroenteritis. Rotavirus is distinctively wheel-shaped, making it the expected appearance in stool analysis for this clinical presentation.

Rotavirus

  • Leading cause of childhood diarrhoea; belongs to the Reoviridae family (the only family with double-stranded RNA).

Structure:

 

  • Size: 60–80 nm, icosahedral symmetry with a triple-layered, wheel-shaped capsid.
  • Genome: Segmented dsRNA (11 segments).
  • Proteins:
    • Structural (VP1–VP7, except VP5); VP6 is group-specific.
    • VP7 (outer capsid) and VP4 (spikes) induce neutralizing antibodies.

Classification:

  • Traditional: Seven groups (A–G), with Group A causing most human diarrhoea.

Epidemiology:

  • The major cause of pediatric gastroenteritis worldwide is outbreaks, which are common in areas with poor sanitation and seasonally in temperate zones.

Pathogenesis:

  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route.
  • Action: Infects small intestine enterocytes, causing secretory diarrhoea.
  • NSP4 protein acts as an enterotoxin, altering epithelial function.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: 1–3 days.
  • Manifestations: Vomiting, watery diarrhoea, fever, and abdominal pain. Severe dehydration risk in children.

Diagnosis:

  • Specimen: Stool collected early in the illness.
  • Tests:
    • Immunoelectron microscopy (IEM): Wheel-shaped appearance.
    • Antigen detection: ELISA, latex agglutination.
    • RT-PCR: Most sensitive method.
    • G serotype and P genotype detection via RNA typing.

Vaccines:

  • Rotavac: Live attenuated G9P[10] strain; three oral doses at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.
  • Rotarix: Live attenuated G1P[8] strain; two doses at 6 and 10 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis virus is spread by contaminated water?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

Family:

  • Picornaviridae family
  • Genus: Hepatovirus
  • Also known as Enterovirus-72
  • Single serotype and six genotypes (I, II, III affecting humans)

 

Genotype

Common Locations

I

Worldwide (most prevalent genotype)

II

Found in specific regions (less common)

IIIa

Predominant in India and some Asian countries

 

Viral Morphology:

  • Small, non-enveloped virus
  • Icosahedral symmetry
  • Single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome (+ssRNA)
  • Encodes four capsid proteins (VP1–VP4)

 

Transmission:

  • Fecal-oral route, especially in areas with poor sanitation
  • Spreads through direct contact, contaminated food or water, fomites, or person-to-person contact with inadequate hygiene
  • Rare transmission through blood transfusion and sexual contact
  • In India, over 90% of individuals are seropositive by age 10, indicating widespread early exposure

 

Epidemiology:

  • Similarities with poliovirus (fecal-oral transmission)
  • Seasonal trends, peaking during warmer months due to increased exposure to contaminated food

 

Cultivability:

Can be cultivated in specific cell cultures, such as human or primate diploid cell lines (unlike most hepatitis viruses)

questions.text: Covid-19 can be prevented through all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ivermectin is not used in the treatment of COVID-19.

SARS-CoV-2

 

  • Type: Virus, classified as a coronavirus.
  • Size: Approximately 120 nm with helical symmetry.
  • Components:
    • Nucleocapsid: Positive-sense single-stranded RNA (~30 kb) surrounded by nucleocapsid protein (N).
    • Envelope: Lipoprotein structure with embedded proteins, host-derived.
  • Structural Proteins:
    • Spike Protein (S): Facilitates attachment to host cells; contains two subunits:
      • S1 Subunit: Contains receptor-binding domain (RBD) for host cell attachment.
      • S2 Subunit: Mediates virus-cell membrane fusion.
    • Membrane Glycoprotein (M): Most abundant, provides shape to the virus.
    • Envelope Protein (E): Transmembrane protein with ion channel activity.
  • Non-structural Proteins: Include enzymes like RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) crucial for viral replication.

 

Pathogenesis of COVID-19

Host Cell Entry
  • Binding: Spike glycoprotein (S) attaches to angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE-2) receptors on lung type II alveolar cells.
  • Cleavage: Host proteases (e.g., TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein, facilitating viral entry via the endosomal pathway.

Initial Inflammatory Response
  • Influenza-like Illness (ILI): Infection of the pharyngeal epithelium initiates ILI.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
  • Damage to Alveolar Cells: Impaired type II alveolar cells decrease pulmonary surfactant, causing alveolar collapse and fluid retention.
  • Cytokine Storm: Increased immune cytokine release leads to:
    • Tissue damage and necrosis.
    • Impaired gas exchange and hypoxia.
    • Endothelial damage and microvascular thrombosis.
    • Pulmonary oedema and ground-glass opacities on imaging.
    • Fibrosis and respiratory failure.

Multiorgan Failure
  • Elevated cytokines may harm other organs, resulting in sepsis, septic shock, and acute kidney/cardiac injury.

Risk Factors for Severe Disease
  • Demographics: Age > 60 years.
  • Comorbidities: Diabetes, hypertension, COPD, CKD and cancer.

questions.text:
Match the following viruses with their corresponding nucleic acid type:


	
		
			
			1. Rotavirus
			
			
			A. ssRNA
			
		
		
			
			2. SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19 virus)
			
			
			B. dsRNA
			
		
		
			
			3. Parvovirus
			
			
			C. dsDNA
			
		
		
			
			4. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
			
			
			D. ssDNA
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1- B, 2- A, 3- D, 4- C:

1. Rotavirus

B. dsRNA

2. SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19 virus)

A. ssRNA

3. Parvovirus

D. ssDNA

4. Human papillomavirus (HPV)

C. dsDNA

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D: These options are incorrect options

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a history of painful genital ulcers during pregnancy. Her newborn also has similar ulcers. Examination of a smear reveals the presence of Tzanck cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HSV2:

  • Genital ulcer with child affected with similar lesions points towards diagnosis of HSV2.
  • HSV2 is transmitted vertically and sexually affecting below the waist.
  • Clinical features include genital lesions below waist and Neonatal herpes (mother to child transmission).
  • Other features include: Gingivostomatitis, Encephalitis, Meningitis, and Dendritic ulcers.
  • Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ‘ground glass’ chromatin (Tzanck cells) constitute a positive smear.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - VZV:

  • VZV is a virus similar in morphology to HSV but it causes chicken pox which presents with skin lesions not ulcers.

Option C - HPV:

  • Human papilloma virus causes plantar wart, Epidermodysplasia, Laryngeal papillomatosis, Condyloma accuminata.

Option D - Klebsiella:

  • Klebsiella is a gram negative bacteria which is a common cause of community acquired pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and retro-orbital pain after 5 days, suggestive of dengue hemorrhagic fever. Which investigation is appropriate for confirmation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IgM ELISA:

  • IgM ELISA test offers a reliable diagnosis, usually positive after the 5th day.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option A - NS-1 antigen test:

  • The mainstay of diagnosis is the detection of a non-structural viral protein antigen (NS-1).
  • This can be detected in the blood for up to 1-4 days.

Option B - Viral culture:

  • Viral culture is rarely done in detection of the dengue virus.

Option C - Circulating IGM:

  • Circulating IGM is detected from day 7.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic test for monkeypox?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PCR

Explanation:

  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is the most commonly used and accurate diagnostic test for monkeypox. PCR tests can detect the DNA of the monkeypox virus in clinical samples, such as lesions, blood, or respiratory secretions, allowing for a precise diagnosis.

Monkeypox infections
  • The monkeypox virus belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus.
  • Monkeypox is a rare zoonotic infection first recognized in captive monkeys in 1958.

Transmission
  • Infection likely occurs through direct contact with wild animals.
  • The exact primary reservoir host remains unidentified, but species such as squirrels, rabbits, and rodents can be infected.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms resemble those of smallpox but are generally milder.
  • Fever and rash.
  • Lymphadenopathy is a prominent feature in most cases, unlike in smallpox or chickenpox.

Complications
  • Respiratory distress
  • Secondary bacterial infections

Vaccination

The vaccinia vaccine can offer protection against monkeypox or lessen its severity.

Human-to-Human transmission
  • Transmission between humans is considered limited.
  • Estimates suggest that only about 15% of close contacts of infected individuals become infected.

Diagnosis
  • The CDC recommends the collection of two specimens, each from multiple lesions from different locations.
  • Confirmed via isolation in viral culture or by PCR for mpox virus DNA from a patient specimen.

Incorrect Options:

ELISA (Option A): While ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) can be used to detect antibodies or antigens, it is not the gold standard for diagnosing monkeypox. It may be used to detect antibodies in some cases but is not as definitive as PCR.

Hemagglutination assay (Option B): This test is used for detecting viruses like influenza or other viruses that cause red blood cell agglutination. It is not commonly used for diagnosing monkeypox.

Hybrid Capture assay (Option D): This is primarily used for detecting viral DNA, such as for HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infections, and is not used for monkeypox.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the genital area. On examination, there is a painful vesicle. Further examination also reveals tender lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HSV-2

Explanation:

The scenario of painful genital ulcers, flu-like symptoms, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a history of multiple sexual partners is most likely indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV 2) infection.

Genital lesions of HSV

  • Mostly seen in HSV type 2.
  • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions.

  • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
    • Males: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
  • Females: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum
  • It is associated with systemic features like fever (flu-like) and malaise.
  • In pregnant females, a cesarean is preferred over normal labour to prevent vertical transmission.

Molluscum (Option B): Molluscum contagiosum, caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus, presents as painless, dome-shaped, umbilicated papules. It does not cause vesicular lesions or significant lymphadenopathy.

HPV (Option C): Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes genital warts, which appear as painless, verrucous growths (condyloma acuminata). Unlike HSV-2, HPV does not present with painful vesicles or tender lymphadenopathy.

HZV (Option D): Herpes zoster virus (HZV) causes painful vesicular eruptions following a dermatomal distribution. While it can affect the genital area (e.g., sacral zoster), it does not typically cause inguinal lymphadenopathy unless secondarily infected.

questions.text: A person is bitten by a dog. The dog and the person are fully immunized against rabies. There is a laceration at the site of the bite. What would you advise to the person?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amoxiclav

Explanation:

  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) is the preferred antibiotic for dog bite wounds because it provides broad coverage against Gram-positive, Gram-negative, and anaerobic bacteria, including Pasteurella multocida.
  • Since the patient has a laceration, antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended to prevent secondary bacterial infections.

Metronidazole (Option A): Metronidazole is effective against anaerobic bacteria but is not the first-line prophylactic treatment for dog bites, which often involve aerobic and anaerobic polymicrobial infections, including Pasteurella multocida, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus species.

Ciprofloxacin (Option B): Ciprofloxacin is primarily effective against Gram-negative bacteria but has limited activity against Pasteurella multocida, a common pathogen in dog bites. It is not the preferred first-line antibiotic for animal bites.

Observation (Option D): While observation is appropriate for minor scratches or superficial wounds in an immunized person, a laceration presents a higher risk of bacterial infection, warranting antibiotic prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which statement about rubella is incorrect?

choices.text: It is one of the teratogenic TORCH infections
Causes maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads caudally to involve the trunk and extremities

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is a Flavivirus

Explanation:

  • Rubella is caused by a Togavirus (Rubivirus genus), not a Flavivirus.
  • Flaviviruses include Dengue, Yellow Fever, Zika, and West Nile Virus, whereas Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

CONGENITAL RUBELLA SYNDROME

Definition
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs in infants who have contracted rubella from their mothers while in utero.
  • The most likely time for this to occur is between 8-10 weeks of gestation.
  • After birth, these babies can transmit the virus to others for a period of 12–18 months.

Dermatological presentation
  • Blueberry Muffin Rash (Option D ruled out)
  • Forchheimer Spots- small, red or purple spots that can appear on the soft palate

Ophthalmic Defects
  • Cataracts
  • Microphthalmia
  • Glaucoma
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Chorioretinitis

Auditory Defects
  • Sensorineural deafness

Cardiac Defects
  • Peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Ventricular septal defects

Craniofacial Defects
  • Microcephaly

Other Infant Presentations
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Interstitial pneumonitis
  • Radiolucency in the long bones

 

Diagnosis

 
  • Hemagglutination inhibition test (HAI) is the commonly preferred test.
  • Presence of IgM antibodies shortly after birth.
  • Presence of IgG antibodies lasting >6 months.
  • IgM positive implies in-utero infection because IgM antibodies cannot pass from mother to child through the placenta.

 

Blueberry muffin rash:

Forchheimer Spots

It is one of the teratogenic TORCH infections (Option A): Rubella is a part of the TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other [Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19], Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes Simplex Virus), which can cause congenital defects if contracted during pregnancy.

Causes maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads caudally to involve the trunk and extremities (Option B): Rubella presents with a mild maculopapular rash that begins on the face and then spreads downward to the trunk and extremities, similar to measles but less severe.

questions.text: A child presents with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

 

Explanation:

  • Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease are commonly triggered by Parvovirus B19 infection, which causes transient red cell aplasia.
  • This is because Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to a temporary halt in erythropoiesis.
  • This virus causes cell lysis and depletion of erythroid precursors, leading to transient arrest of erythropoiesis, which exacerbates anemia in children with sickle cell disease.

 

Clinical Manifestations and Complications of Parvovirus B19 Infection

  • Low grade fever, malaise, URTI.
  • Erythema infectiosum (Fifth Disease): Characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the body.
  • Arthropathy: Common in adults, presenting as arthritis or arthralgia.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis: Severe anaemia in individuals with chronic hemolytic anaemia.
  • Fetal Infection: Risk of nonimmune fetal hydrops and stillbirth typically results in normal deliveries.
  • Papular purpural gloves and socks syndrome
  • Myocarditis

 

Immunodeficiency (Option B): While Parvovirus B19 can cause chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals, immunodeficiency itself does not directly present as an acute aplastic crisis with a sudden drop in hemoglobin.

 

Lymphoproliferative disorder (Option C): Lymphoproliferative disorders (e.g., leukemias, lymphomas) may present with pancytopenia, but they do not cause a transient aplastic crisis. They are also more likely to be associated with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and abnormal white blood cell counts.

 

BK Nephropathy (Option D): BK virus mainly affects renal transplant recipients or immunocompromised patients, leading to nephropathy and renal dysfunction, but it does not cause an aplastic crisis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the hospital with symptoms of hydrophobia, which is often associated with rabies infection. The clinician decides to perform further diagnostic tests on the patient's corneal scraping to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following tests is the most appropriate and accurate for confirming the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - RT- PCR

  • This is the correct answer. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a highly sensitive and specific method for detecting viral RNA, including the RNA of the rabies virus. It can be used in various types of samples, including saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, skin biopsies, and corneal scrapings. It is therefore the most appropriate test for confirming a diagnosis of rabies.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Viral culture: While viral culture can be used to diagnose many types of viral infections, it is not typically used for rabies due to the slow growth of the virus and the biohazard risk associated with culturing the rabies virus.

Option C - Antibody detection by ELISA: ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) can be used to detect antibodies against the rabies virus in the patient's blood. However, it can take 1-2 weeks after the onset of symptoms for these antibodies to develop, so a negative result does not rule out rabies in the early stages of the disease.

Option D - Direct fluorescent antibody test: This test is used to detect the presence of rabies virus in a sample (often a skin biopsy from the back of the neck) by staining it with fluorescent antibodies that bind to the virus. While it's a common method for diagnosing rabies, its sensitivity can be lower than RT-PCR, especially in corneal scrapings.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with fever and retro-orbital headache for 2 days. Her Tourniquet test and NS1 antigen are positive, suggesting Dengue infection. Which of the following findings qualifies as a severe dengue criterion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) AST and ALT >1000

Explanation:

  • Severe dengue (Dengue hemorrhagic fever grade III & IV / Dengue shock syndrome) criteria include:
    • Severe plasma leakage → leading to shock or fluid accumulation (pleural effusion/ascites).
    • Severe bleeding.
    • Severe organ involvement:
      • Liver: AST/ALT >1000 U/L (marker of severe hepatitis).
      • CNS involvement: Encephalitis, seizures.
      • Myocarditis, renal failure.

Clinical presentation of Dengue:

Uncategorised fever

  • No typical features

Break bone fever

(Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection)

 
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Arthralgia
  • Severe myalgia and headache
  • Bimodal presentation of fever:
    • 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2
    • Resurges: day 5-6
    • Recovery: day 7-10.
  • Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day.

Dengue haemorrhagic syndrome
  • Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice)
  • Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform
  • Lab diagnosis
    • 20% increase in hematocrit
    • Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac)
  • Clinical diagnosis
    • Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area

Dengue shock syndrome
  • Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg
  • Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children.

Dengue complications

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus
    • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis
  • GBS
  • Stroke

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis

 
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults)

Leucopenia plus thrombocytopenia (Option A): Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³) and leucopenia are common findings in dengue fever, but they do not indicate severe dengue unless associated with bleeding, shock, or organ involvement.

Persistent vomiting (Option B): It is a warning sign for dengue progression, but alone does not classify as severe dengue.

Hepatomegaly >1 cm (Option C): Mild hepatomegaly is seen in dengue, but it becomes severe only when associated with AST/ALT >1000 U/L.

questions.text: An 18-day-old baby presents with fever and cough. On examination, vesicles are observed over the trunk and upper limb. The mother had genital ulcers one year ago, which have since resolved. Biopsy of the vesicles reveals multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

Explanation:

Neonatal HSV infection typically results from vertical transmission during vaginal delivery, especially if the mother had genital HSV infection.

  • The presence of vesicles in a newborn with a maternal history of genital ulcers strongly suggests neonatal herpes simplex infection.
  • Microscopic features
    • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
    • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) (Option B): MCV causes pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, not vesicles.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option C): HPV is associated with warts, not vesicular lesions.

Varicella (Option D): Varicella (chickenpox) also causes vesicular rash, but it is less likely in a neonate unless there is maternal varicella exposure close to delivery. Multinucleated giant cells can be seen in both HSV and VZV, but maternal history of genital ulcers favors HSV over varicella.

questions.text: Which of the following viral infections has the least teratogenicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Herpes Simplex Virus-2

Explanation:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus-2 rarely causes congenital malformations. Neonatal herpes is usually acquired perinatally during vaginal delivery, leading to skin, eye, and mouth (SEM) disease, encephalitis, or disseminated disease, but not congenital structural defects.
  • Not a significant teratogen compared to CMV, rubella, or varicella.
  • TORCH infections include toxoplasmosis, rubella, CMV, Herpes and HIV.

Vertical transmission of diseases.

1st trimester

Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella

2nd trimester

Parvovirus

3rd trimester

Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis.

During delivery

HIV and herpes

 

Infection

Pathogen & Transmission

Clinical Features

Toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasma gondii (transplacental from infected mother, cat feces, undercooked meat)

Classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications; anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, seizures, intellectual disability

Varicella

(Option B ruled out)

Varicella-zoster virus (aerosols, direct contact, transplacental)

Congenital varicella syndrome: skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, neurodevelopmental delay

Syphilis

Treponema pallidum (sexual transmission, transplacental, peripartum)

Stillbirth, Hutchinson triad (notched teeth, interstitial keratitis, deafness), skeletal abnormalities

Parvovirus B19

Parvovirus B19 (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Hydrops fetalis, neurodevelopmental defects, fetal anemia

Rubella

(Option D ruled out)

Rubella virus (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Congenital rubella syndrome: sensorineural deafness, cataracts, congenital heart disease, hepatosplenomegaly

Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

(Option A ruled out)

CMV (body fluids, blood transfusion, organ transplant, transplacental, peripartum, breast milk)

Leading cause of non-genetic congenital hearing loss, petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, neurodevelopmental deficits

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1 & HSV-2)

HSV (direct contact, mucosal exposure, peripartum)

Neonatal herpes: vesicular rash, encephalitis, seizures, bulging fontanelle, viral sepsis, organ failure

questions.text: A patient with HIV presents with white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa. These patches cannot be removed by scraping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epstein-Barr Virus

Explanation:

  • Oral Hairy Leukoplakia is caused by EBV and is strongly associated with HIV/AIDS.
  • It presents as painless, white, corrugated patches on the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the buccal mucosa.
  • Unlike oral candidiasis, these lesions cannot be scraped off.

 

Candida (Option B): Oral candidiasis (thrush) is common in HIV, but the white plaques can be scraped off, leaving an erythematous base.

  • Confirmed with potassium hydroxide (KOH) prep, showing budding yeast and pseudohyphae.

HSV (Option C): HSV causes painful vesicles or ulcers rather than white plaques.

HHV-8 (Option D): HHV-8 is associated with Kaposi sarcoma, which presents as vascular, reddish-purple nodules, not white plaques

questions.text: The HIV genome requires which of the following to initiate the process of entering the host cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GP120

Explanation:

GP120 (Glycoprotein 120) is the first viral protein involved in HIV entry.

  • It binds to the CD4 receptor on host T-helper cells (CD4+ cells).
  • After binding to CD4, GP120 undergoes a conformational change, allowing it to interact with co-receptors (CCR5 or CXCR4), facilitating viral entry.

HIV is a spherical virus and its capsid has an icosahedral symmetry and also contains two copies of single-stranded positive-sense RNA in its core.

Structure of HIV

  • HIV is a spherical virus measuring 80–110 nm in diameter and belongs to the lentivirus family. Its structure includes:
  • Envelope: Composed of:
    • Lipid Component: Derived from the host cell membrane.
    • Protein Component:
      • gp120: Glycoprotein forming knob-like spikes on the surface.
      • gp41: Glycoprotein that acts as anchoring transmembrane pedicles. (Option C ruled out)
  • Nucleocapsid: The capsid has an icosahedral symmetry and contains core proteins. Inside, there is a dense cylindrical inner core that houses:
    • RNA: Two identical copies of single-stranded positive-sense linear RNA.
    • Viral Enzymes: Including reverse transcriptase, integrase, and proteases, which are closely associated with the RNA.

HIV Serotyping

Serotypes: HIV is classified into two main serotypes: HIV-1 and HIV-2.

  • HIV-1 Groups:
    • Divided into groups M, N, O, and a proposed group P.
    • Group M: Dominant globally with eleven subtypes (A-K) and circulating recombinant forms (CRFs).

Quasispecies: Hosts may have multiple closely related viral subtypes or CRFs.

  • Geographical Distribution:
    • Subtype A: Common in West Africa.
    • Subtype B: Predominant in Europe, America, Japan, and Australia.
    • Subtype C: Most common worldwide (47%); dominant in Southern/Eastern Africa, India, and China.
    • Cameroon: High diversity and possible origin of the virus.

Transmission:

  • Subtypes C and E are more often transmitted heterosexually.
  • Subtype B spreads primarily through blood and homosexual contact.

 

  • HIV-2: Comprises eight subtypes (A–H), mainly found in Africa and parts of India, with Group A being the most common.

 

CCR5 (Option B) & CXCR4 (Option D):

  • Co-receptors needed after GP120 binding.
  • CCR5 → Used by R5-tropic HIV strains (mostly during early infection).
  • CXCR4 → Used by X4-tropic HIV strains (seen in later stages, more aggressive

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3-day history of fever. Complete blood count (CBC) showed a platelet count of <90,000. For a suspicion of dengue, which of the following cannot be done on day 3 of infection?

choices.text: Xenodiagnosis using culture in Aedes mosquito

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IgM ELISA

Explanation:

Dengue-specific IgM antibodies typically appear around day 4 of illness.

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Fever: Must be present.
  • Any 2 of the following 6 features:
    • Retroorbital pain, myalgia, or "break-bone fever"
    • Protracted nausea or vomiting: Can lead to dehydration
    • Rash: Observed during the illness
    • Warning signs: Any 1 positive sign (e.g., severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting)
    • Positive tourniquet test:
      • >20 petechiae per square inch
      • BP cuff inflated between systolic and diastolic blood pressure
      • The cuff inflated for 5 minutes
    • Leucopenia: Decreased white blood cell count

Investigations

Test Type

Description

ELISA
  • IgM dengue virus (MAC-ELISA)
  • Positive by Day 4 of infection
  • Indicates recent infection

NAAT
  • Detects viral RNA
  • Useful for early diagnosis

NS-1 Antigen

(Option B ruled out)
  • NS-1 (IgG)
  • Positive on Day 1 of infection
  • Should be performed within 7 days of symptom onset

 

PCR (Option A): Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is used to detect dengue viral RNA and is highly sensitive in the early phase of infection, typically within the first 5 days. It is useful for confirming the diagnosis in the acute stage.

Xenodiagnosis using culture in Aedes mosquito (Option D): Xenodiagnosis involves infecting mosquitoes with a patient’s blood to detect the virus. While not a standard clinical diagnostic method, it theoretically could be performed on day 3. However, its practical use is limited to research settings rather than routine diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses are required to undergo reverse transcription for PCR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RSV

Explanation:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is an RNA virus belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family. Since PCR typically amplifies DNA, reverse transcription is required to convert the viral RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) before PCR can proceed.

 

EBV (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a DNA virus belonging to the Herpesviridae family. As a DNA virus, it does not require reverse transcription for PCR.

CMV (Option C): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is another Herpesviridae family member and a DNA virus. PCR can directly amplify its DNA, so reverse transcription is unnecessary.

Adenovirus (Option D): Adenoviruses are non-enveloped DNA viruses. Like other DNA viruses, they do not require reverse transcription for PCR.

questions.text:
A patient hailing from Delhi presents with high fever, arthralgia, retrobulbar pain, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations reveal:


	Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
	WBC count: 9000 cells/mm³
	Platelet count: 20,000 cells/mm³
	Positive tourniquet test


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dengue hemorrhagic fever

Explanation:

  • Dengue hemorrhagic fever is characterized by high fever, thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³), plasma leakage (leading to hemoconcentration, pleural effusion, or ascites), and hemorrhagic manifestations (petechiae, gum bleeding, or positive tourniquet test). The patient’s low platelet count (20,000/mm³) and petechiae confirm this diagnosis.

Dengue complications

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus
    • Linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis
  • GBS
  • Stroke

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • Co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults)

Incorrect Options:

Dengue fever (Option A): Classical dengue fever presents with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, retro-orbital pain, and rash but does not involve significant thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³) or plasma leakage. The presence of petechiae and a positive tourniquet test suggests progression to Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF).

Dengue shock syndrome (Option C): Dengue shock syndrome is a severe complication of DHF, with hypotension, circulatory collapse, and organ failure. The absence of shock symptoms (low BP, tachycardia, cold extremities, altered sensorium) rules out DSS.

Malaria (Option D): Malaria presents with cyclic fevers, chills, sweating, and anemia. While severe Plasmodium falciparum infection can cause thrombocytopenia, petechial rash and a positive tourniquet test are not typical findings.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and rash. Urine examination shows cells with an "owl-eye" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cytomegalovirus

Explanation:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is associated with "owl-eye" intranuclear inclusions in infected cells, which are enlarged and found in urine, blood, or tissue biopsy.
  • In neonates, congenital CMV can present with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and petechial rash.
  • In immunocompromised patients, CMV can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, and colitis.

Cytomegalovirus

General Characteristics
  • Herpesvirus (HHV-5), widespread prevalence.
  • Often asymptomatic in healthy individuals but severe in immunocompromised and congenital infections.
  • Remains latent post-infection and may reactivate.
  • Linked to mucoepidermoid carcinoma and possibly prostate cancer.
  • Transmission: Blood transfusions, organ transplantation, breastfeeding, close contact, perinatal, and sexual routes.
  • Reactivation occurs in immunocompromised individuals, increasing morbidity and mortality.

Pathophysiology
  • Persists in myeloid cells, reactivates with immune suppression.
  • Controlled mainly by cytotoxic T-cell immunity.
  • Lifelong immune burden, affecting T-cell surveillance.

Clinical Manifestations
  • Immunocompetent patients: Often asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like syndrome (fever, rash, leukocytosis).
  • Immunocompromised patients: Can cause severe organ-specific disease:
  • CMV hepatitis → Risk of fulminant liver failure
  • CMV retinitis → “Pizza pie” fundoscopic appearance
  • CMV esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, polyradiculopathy, encephalitis, transverse myelitis

Diagnosis
  • Quantitative PCR: Preferred for viral detection.
  • Histopathology (CMV inclusion bodies): Gold standard.
  • Serology: Used for pre-transplant risk assessment but not for acute infection diagnosis.
  • CMV-negative blood transfusions reserved for neonates and immunocompromised patients.
  • Ganciclovir resistance testing is routine in transplant centers.

Management
  • Immunocompetent patients: Self-limiting, only symptomatic treatment required.
  • Immunocompromised & severe cases: Require antivirals (ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir).
  • Prophylaxis: CMV-negative recipients of CMV-positive organ transplants should receive valganciclovir or ganciclovir with serological monitoring.
  • Antiviral toxicity must be weighed against benefits.

Incorrect Options:

Epstein-Barr virus (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis, which presents with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. It is associated with atypical lymphocytes in blood smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions in urine.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes painful vesicular lesions in the oral or genital region. It shows multinucleated giant cells with Cowdry type A inclusions on Tzanck smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): Toxoplasma gondii causes congenital toxoplasmosis, which presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. It is a protozoan, and its cysts do not show "owl-eye" inclusions.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

Explanation:

  • Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and latex agglutination tests are commonly used to detect rotavirus antigen (VP6 protein) in stool samples. This is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing rotavirus infection.

Sandwich ELISA Procedure:

  1. Coating: Coat microtiter wells with goat anti-rotavirus antibody; add sample and incubate (overnight at 4°C or 2 hours at 37°C).
  2. Detection Antibody: Add enzyme-labelled anti-rotavirus antibody (e.g., with alkaline phosphatase) and incubate.
  3. Substrate Addition: Add para-nitrophenyl phosphate; enzyme activity causes colour change if rotavirus is present.
  4. Interpretation: Yellow colour development confirms a positive test; the ELISA reader provides quantitative colour readings.

Incorrect Options:

Antigen detection in blood (Option B): Rotavirus primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract and does not cause significant viremia; therefore, detecting antigens in blood is not a standard diagnostic method.

Antibody detection in serum (Option C): While serology can detect past exposure to rotavirus, it is not useful for acute diagnosis, as antibodies appear later in the infection.

Light microscopy of stool specimen (Option D): Routine light microscopy does not detect rotavirus, as the virus is too small to be seen. However, electron microscopy can visualize viral particles but is not routinely used due to cost and expertise requirements.

questions.text: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

Explanation:

  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HSV DNA in CSF is the gold standard for diagnosing HSV encephalitis due to its high sensitivity and specificity.

HSV Encephalitis
  • Herpesviruses: Large, double-stranded DNA viruses; 8 types affect humans (HHV-1 to HHV-8).
  • HSV Types:
    • HSV-1: Most common in adults & children; sporadic, non-seasonal.
    • HSV-2: More common in neonates & immunocompromised individuals.

Etiology
  • Causative Agents: HSV-1 (90%), HSV-2 (10%).
  • Structure: Enveloped, icosahedral, double-stranded DNA virus.
  • Host Cell Entry: Via nectin-1 and HVEM receptors on neurons.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Primary infection: HSV infects skin/mucosa, enters neurons, and travels retrogradely to ganglia.
    • Latency: Controlled by immune mechanisms (histone deposition, cytokines).
    • Reactivation: Can spread to CNS via trigeminal or olfactory nerves.

Pathophysiology
  • Transmission: Close contact; HSV-1 → oral, HSV-2 → genital.
  • Brain Invasion Routes:
    1. Oropharyngeal infection → Trigeminal/Olfactory nerve spread.
    2. Reactivation in ganglia → CNS spread.
    3. Latent HSV in the brain reactivates.
  • Affected Areas: Temporal lobes, limbic system → hemorrhagic necrosis.
  • Immunosuppression Risks: Natalizumab, TNF-α inhibitors, whole-brain radiation.

Clinical Presentation
  • Prodrome: Fever, malaise, headache, nausea.
  • Typical Features:
    • CNS signs: Confusion, seizures, focal deficits, personality changes.
    • Behavioral syndromes: Hypomania, Klüver-Bucy, amnesia.
    • Other findings: Incontinence, dermatomal rash, Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • Neonatal HSE:
    • Presents at 1–3 weeks with irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, tremors, seizures.
    • Herpetic skin lesions, thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction may be present.
  • Immunocompromised Patients: Atypical/subtle presentation, fewer focal deficits.

Histopathology
  • Gross Findings: Hemorrhagic necrosis in medial temporal and inferior frontal lobes.
  • Microscopic Findings:
    • Early: Neuronal ischemia, capillary dilation.
    • Cowdry type A inclusions: Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions in neurons.
    • Late (>3 weeks): Necrosis, gliosis, inflammation.
  • Atypical in Immunocompromised: Less inflammation, persistent viral antigens.

Evaluation
  • CSF Analysis (Gold Standard):
    • ↑ WBCs (lymphocytic pleocytosis), ↑ protein, normal glucose.
    • HSV PCR: 96% sensitive, 99% specific.
    • Repeat PCR if negative within 72 hours in high-suspicion cases.
    • HSV IgM in CSF is useful if PCR is unavailable or delayed.
  • Imaging:
    • CT: Initial test; may be normal early, later shows hypodensities, hemorrhage.
    • MRI (Best Test): Temporal lobe hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR, sparing basal ganglia.
  • Other Tests:
    • CBC, metabolic panel.
    • HSV PCR in blood useful in neonates & immunocompromised.

Incorrect Options:

IgM in CSF (Option A): IgM detection is not reliable for diagnosing HSV encephalitis because antibody production is delayed, and false negatives are common in early infection.

Tzanck smear of CSF (Option B): Tzanck smear is used for HSV skin and mucosal lesions but is not useful for diagnosing CNS infections. It detects multinucleated giant cells, which are not seen in CSF.

CSF culture on chick embryo lines (Option D): HSV culture requires human cell lines (not chick embryos), and CSF cultures are rarely positive in encephalitis. Culture is not a reliable diagnostic method for CNS infections.

questions.text: What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - H. Influenzae :

  • Haemophilus influenzae - Small gram ⊝ (coccobacillary) rod. Aerosol transmission. Nontypeable (unencapsulated) strains are the most common cause of mucosal infections (otitis media, conjunctivitis, bronchitis) as well as invasive infections since the vaccine for capsular type b was introduced. Produces IgA protease. Culture on chocolate agar, which contains factors V (NAD+ ) and X (hematin) for growth; can also be grown with S aureus, which provides factor V via RBC hemolysis. Haemophilus causes epiglottitis (endoscopic appearance ) , can be “cherry red” in children; “thumb sign” on lateral neck x-ray  ), meningitis, otitis media, and pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): This option is incorrect

Option C - Parainfluenza virus: This option is incorrect

Option D - Newcastle disease virus: This option is incorrect

questions.text:
Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly?

1. Varicella zoster virus

2. Rota virus

3. Influenza vaccine

4. Pneumococcal Meningitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, and 4

 

Explanation:

Vaccination against varicella zoster virus is recommended as latent VZV Infection can reactivate as herpes zoster or shingles.

  • As age advances, cell-mediated immune responses (CMI) to VZV decline, with resultant increased incidence of reactivation as herpes zoster among older people.
  • The Influenza vaccine is highly recommended in the elderly to prevent severe disease.
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) is given to people aged 65 and over. It helps prevent meningitis and other illnesses caused by 23 strains of pneumococcal bacteria

 

Vaccination recommended in elderly are:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine
  • Influenza vaccine
  • Varicella zoster vaccine
  • Covid 19 vaccine
  • Td vaccine

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs of diseases and their corresponding populations related to parvovirus is incorrect?

1. Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

2. Viral envelop - Naked virus

3. Erythema infectiosum - infants

4. Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4


 

Explanation:

leading to the characteristic rash.

 

Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:


 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: The image below shows the structure of a virus, which of the following proteins act as oncogenes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) E6, E7

 

Explanation:

HPV has two oncoproteins, E6 and E7, which are responsible for the development of HPV-induced carcinogenesis.

  • E6 will inactivate p53, and E7 will inactivate the RB gene, which leads to cancer.
  • They act as oncogenes.

 

Structure of HPV

Function

L1 capsid protein

Used for making a vaccine

E2

Controller

E4 & E5

Responsible for making a change in the cell called Koilocytosis.

E6 & E7

Responsible for Carcinogenesis

questions.text: If a patient's plasma contains elevated levels of interferon beta, it is indicative of a probable infection caused by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Virus

 

Explanation:

Interferon beta (IFN-β) is produced by fibroblasts in response to viral infections, particularly when the body detects the presence of viral RNA or other viral components. Elevated levels of IFN-β are typically indicative of a viral infection because it plays a role in the innate immune response, helping to limit viral replication.

Interferons (IFNs):

  • Types:
    • IFN-α: Produced by macrophages, has antiviral action.
    • IFN-β: Produced by fibroblasts, also has antiviral action.
    • IFN-γ: Produced by T helper cells, does not have antiviral action but plays a role in cell-mediated immunity (CMI).
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • IFNs do not directly act on viruses but stimulate host cells to produce proteins that inhibit protein synthesis and viral replication.
  • Innate Immunity:
    • IFNs are part of innate immunity, nonspecific, and produced quickly after infection (within hours).
    • Unlike antibodies, they don’t have immunological memory.
  • Inducers:
    • IFN production is triggered by agents like RNA viruses (e.g., togaviruses, vesicular stomatitis virus), double-stranded RNA, bacterial endotoxin, and synthetic polymers.
  • Preparations:
    • Human IFNs: Prepared via DNA recombinant technology.
    • Pegylated IFNs: IFN-α linked to polyethylene glycol, resulting in slower absorption, decreased clearance, and more sustained serum levels. Administered once a week.
  • Clinical Applications:
    • Topical: Used for rhinovirus infections, genital warts, and herpetic keratitis.
    • Systemic: Used for chronic hepatitis B, C, and D infections.
    • Antiproliferative Action: Used to treat cancers (e.g., hairy cell leukemia, Kaposi’s sarcoma) and autoimmune diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis).

 

Bacteria (Option B), Fungi (Option C), and Mycoplasma (Option D): While infections caused by these pathogens may also trigger immune responses, they typically don't induce the production of interferon beta in the same way viruses do. Instead, bacterial infections often activate other components of the immune system, such as neutrophils and macrophages, and induce the release of cytokines like interleukin-1 or tumor necrosis factor (TNF), rather than IFN-β.

questions.text: Petechial rash is seen in all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Roseola infantum

 

Explanation:

Roseola infantum/Sixth disease/exanthem subitum is caused by herpes virus 6.

  • It is characterized by fever and characteristic nagayama spots,
  • Nagayama spots: Erythematous, rose pink, non-pruritic papules after fever.

 

  • The child's sudden high fever, followed by a rose-coloured maculopapular rash, indicates roseola infantum, primarily caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). While HHV-6 causes the condition, HHV-7 is related and can cause similar illnesses.
  • HHV-6 shows some antigenic cross-reactivity with HHV-7, and both bind to T-cells via CD46
  • HHV-6 has 2 variants, i.e. A and B.
  • Both HHV 6 & 7 spreads through saliva.

Conditions caused

HHV 6
  • In children: Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum (sudden high fever followed by a distinctive rash)
  • In adults: Infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms and focal encephalitis
  • In Immunodeficient - Pneumonia and Disseminated disease.

HHV 7

Causes Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum in children

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibit genetic re assortment?
questions.solution:
Virus which have segmented genome will show genetic reassortment in which co-infection of a host cell with multiple viruses results in the shuffling of gene segments to generate progeny viruses with novel genome combinations.

  • Reassortment is exclusively seen in viruses with a segmented genome.
  • It is defined as the exchange of intact genes within the entire segment, which occurs during confection.

 

Orthomyxovirus (Influenza Virus) Segments and Structure:

 

  • Genera: Includes influenza A, B, C, and D viruses.
  • Genome Segments:
    • Influenza A and B: Eight segments of negative-sense, single-stranded RNA.
    • Influenza C and D: Seven segments (lacking the segment coding for neuraminidase).
  • Shape and Size:
    • Spherical, approximately 80–120 nm in diameter.
    • Helical symmetry with a helical nucleocapsid enclosed in an envelope.
  • Replication Site:
    • Unique among RNA viruses, replication occurs in the nucleus.
  • Viral Proteins:
    • Structural Proteins:
      • Polymerase proteins: PB1, PB2, and PA are responsible for RNA transcription and replication.
      • Nucleoprotein (NP): Forms a ribonucleoprotein complex with viral RNA.
      • Matrix proteins: M1 forms a shell beneath the envelope; M2 forms ion channels in the envelope.
      • Glycoproteins: Hemagglutinin (HA) binds sialic acid receptors for viral entry; Neuraminidase (NA) aids in viral release and prevents virion aggregation.
    • Non-structural Proteins:
      • NS1 acts as an interferon antagonist.
      • NS2 aids in nuclear export.
  • Envelope:
    • Lipid envelope containing HA and NA glycoproteins, which are essential for host cell entry and virus release.
    • Hemagglutinin:
      • Triangular-shaped peplomer.
      • Binds to mucin or sialic acid receptors on respiratory epithelial cells.
      • Facilitates viral entry into host cells.
    • Neuraminidase:
      • Mushroom-shaped and present in fewer numbers than HA.
      • Sialidase enzyme that degrades sialic acid receptors on host cells.
      • Facilitates release of virus particles from infected cell surfaces during budding.
      • Prevents self-aggregation of virions to host cells.
      • Helps the virus pass through the mucin layer in the respiratory tract to reach target epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Erythema infectiosum

Explanation:

Parvovirus

Morphology

  • Simplest animal viruses infecting humans, responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Smallest viruses (18–26 nm in size).
  • Non-enveloped with icosahedral symmetry.
  • Only DNA viruses with single-stranded DNA.
  • Dependent on host cell enzymes for replication.

Pathogenesis
  • Exclusively infects humans.
  • Transmission:
  • Primarily through the respiratory route.
  • Blood transfusion.
  • Transplacental transmission.
  • Target Cells: Tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in adult bone marrow and fetal liver.
  • Receptor Binding: Binds to blood group P antigen on RBC surface.
  • Effects: Leads to RBC destruction and inhibition of erythropoiesis, potentially causing anemia.

 

 

Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) (Option A )
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. (Option B)

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: Condyloma acuminata is most commonly caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HPV 6, 11

Explanation:

Condyloma acuminata means anogenital warts characterized by small, light brown, gray, or skin-colored bumps caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). They are usually painless but can grow large and cause itching and bleeding. The most common strains of HPV that cause anogenital warts are 6 and 11. The virus can infect the skin of the genitals, anus, mouth, and throat.

Condyloma accuminata (anogenital warts):

  • Benign, moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia and has low malignant potential. Caused by HPV 6,11.
  • Site: They may be found in the genital area such as the penile shaft, scrotum, or labia majora of the vagina, or in the anal area.
  • Appearance: They are generally pink and project out from the surface of the skin. Size may vary; they usually appear small but can merge into large masses.
  • Microscopy:
    • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma.
    • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening).
    • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is Characteristic.
    • No evidence of dysplasia.

Clinical lesion

Oncogenic potential

HPV types

Plantar warts

Benign

1

Common skin warts

Benign

2, 4, 27, 57

Epidermodysplasia verrucosa

Mostly benign, rarely progresses to malignancy

5, 8, 9, 12, 17
  • Anogenital warts
  • Laryngeal papilloma
  • Intraepithelial neoplasia

Low malignant potential

6, 11

Palmar warts in butchers

Low malignant potential

7

Carcinomas of the cervix & other genital mucosa/larynx/oesophagus

High malignant potential

16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling, and his jaw is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mumps

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week, testicular swelling and jaw swelling is indicative of Mumps.
  • Mumps is a paramyxovirus. It presents with non-specific symptoms like fever, myalgia, and anorexia, and specific symptoms:
    • Bilateral parotitis, the most common presentation, is characterized by acute non-suppurative enlargement of the gland.
    • Second most common manifestation - unilateral orchitis (male) and oophoritis (female), develops in 15–30% of cases in postpubertal males. Orchitis is unilateral in most of the cases.

 

Complications of Mumps

Orchitis (Option B)

The most common extra salivary gland manifestation of mumps in post pubertal patients.

Common among adolescents and is usually unilateral.

Oophoritis

Most common among adolescents and is mostly unilateral.

Pancreatitis

Mumps is the leading cause of pancreatitis in children.

Aseptic Meningitis

The most common complication of mumps.

Sensorineural Deafness

Mumps is one of the most common infectious causes of sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Croup (Option A) is a common respiratory illness of the trachea, larynx, and bronchi that can lead to inspiratory stridor and barking cough. The parainfluenza virus and H. influenza.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option C) aka kissing disease is most frequently caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), characterized by fever, sore throat, arthralgia, lethargy, and organomegaly (splenomegaly).

Herpangina (Option D) is an acute febrile fever accompanied by tiny ulcerative or vesicular lesions in the pharynx caused by Coxsackie A virus, and enterovirus 71.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years, with the disease lasting a few days at a time, slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visual and memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, and a diagnosis of Mollaret’s meningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus:

  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • Most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis)
    • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)

Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.

 

Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.

Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler’s herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.

Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)

  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection)

​​​​​​​Recurrent herpes labialis

  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers
  • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
  • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
  • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

Measles virus (Option A) can cause subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) but does not cause recurrent meningitis.

Mumps virus (Option B) is a common cause of viral meningitis, but it is typically non-recurrent and occurs after parotitis.

Rubella virus (Option D) is associated with congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: Reinfection with which of the following viruses can lead to more severe disease with complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dengue

Explanation:

Dengue virus:

  • Dengue virus (DENV) is the most common arbovirus in India, belonging to the Flaviviridae family.
  • It is an enveloped virus with single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • DENV has four serotypes (DEN-1 to DEN-4), with a fifth serotype (DEN-5) discovered in 2013 in Bangkok.

Vector:

  • Vectors: Aedes aegypti (main) and Aedes albopictus; both bite during the day.

Pathogenesis:

  • Primary Dengue Infection: Occurs upon first infection with any one dengue serotype.
  • Secondary Dengue Infection: Results from infection with a different serotype than the one involved in the primary infection.

The secondary infection is more severe and can lead to Dengue hemorrhagic fever or Dengue shock syndrome.

Antibody Response Against Dengue Virus:

  • Dengue virus infection induces both neutralizing and non-neutralizing antibodies.
  • Neutralizing Antibodies: Protective and produced against the infective serotype (lasting for life) and other serotypes (temporary cross-protection).
  • Protection Duration: Lifelong protection against the infective serotype, while cross-protection to other serotypes diminishes over a few months.
  • Non-Neutralizing Antibodies: Last for life and are heterotypic, produced against other serotypes but not the infective ones. During a secondary dengue infection, antibodies produced from the first serotype can bind to the second serotype but fail to neutralize it. Instead, these antibodies enhance the infection by inhibiting immune responses, preventing B cell activation against the second serotype.
  • Antibody-Dependent Enhancement (ADE): This phenomenon leads to the recruitment of mononuclear cells and cytokine release, contributing to increased severity of secondary dengue infections.

Dengue fever (DF): It is characterized by:

  • Abrupt onset of high fever (also called biphasic fever, break bone fever or saddleback fever)
  • Maculopapular rashes over the chest and upper limbs
  • Severe frontal headache
  • Muscle and joint pains
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Retro-orbital pain
  • Loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting

Rabies (Option B) is a viral infection transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal. It is almost always fatal once the symptoms develop.

Measles (Option C) is a highly contagious viral infection. Although reinfection with measles is possible, it does not typically lead to more severe disease or complications.

Mumps (Option D) is a viral infection that primarily affects the parotid gland and salivary glands, leading to swelling and pain. Reinfection with mumps is rare.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HIV

Explanation:

  • Structural genes
    • GAG gene encodes the core structural proteins of the virus
      • p24: capsid protein
      • p17: matrix protein
    • POL gene encodes enzymes crucial for viral replication
      • Reverse transcriptase
      • Integrase
      • Protease
    • ENV gene encodes the envelope proteins necessary for virus entry
      • gp120: surface glycoprotein
      • gp41: transmembrane protein
  • Non-Structural Proteins
    • Tat: transcription activator
    • Rev: regulating viral expression
    • Nef: negative Regulatory Factor
    • Vif: Viral infectivity factor
    • Vpr: Viral protein R
    • Vpu: Viral protein U
  • HIV mainly targets immune cells, particularly CD4 cells, and enters the host cells using its envelope glycoprotein, gp120.

The virus's ability to destroy CD4 cells and evade the immune response is central to its pathogenicity, leading to significant immunosuppression and increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections.

EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) (Option B) A dsDNA virus from the Herpesvirus family, has an icosahedral capsid and lacks the characteristic HIV glycoprotein spikes.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) (Option C) is a Herpesvirus, but it is larger and does not have the bullet-shaped core of HIV. It is known for "owl’s eye" inclusion bodies in infected cells.

Coronavirus (Option D) has a crown-like appearance due to large spike proteins (S-protein) and a positive-sense ssRNA genome.

questions.text: An elderly patient was rushed to the casualty following bouts of severe breathlessness. He reported a history of fever and cough for the past 3 days. Lab tests were done, and target sequences for the RdRp gene, E gene, N gene, and ORF1 were detected. What was the test done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Real-time RT-PCR

Explanation:

The detection of the target sequences against the RdRp gene, E gene, N gene, and ORF1 confirms the diagnosis of coronavirus. Real-time RT-PCR is a gold standard test for the diagnosis of coronavirus

Real-Time RT-PCR for COVID-19 Diagnosis

  • Real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) is the gold standard for diagnosing COVID-19.
  • Turnaround Time: The average time from sample receipt to result generation is approximately 4-5 hours.
  • Capacity: Can process up to 90 samples in a single run, making it efficient for frontline testing.
  • Gene Targets:
    • Screening (Genus Specific):
      • Spike protein (S)
      • Envelope protein (E)
      • Membrane protein (M)
      • Nucleocapsid protein (N)
    • Confirmation (Species Specific for SARS-CoV-2):
      • RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp)
      • Open reading frames (ORF1a/b)
      • N2 nucleocapsid
  • Principle of Testing:
    • Qualitative real-time PCR amplifies target genes in the specimen using a thermocycler.
    • Fluorescence is generated when the amplicon binds to the probe, with the cycle threshold (Ct) indicating positivity.
    • A sample is considered positive if both screening and confirmatory genes are detected with a Ct value ≤ 40 cycles.
  • Detectability: NAAT can be positive as early as day 1 of symptom onset (usually 5 days post-infection) and generally declines by the third week, often becoming undetectable thereafter.

Automated Real-Time RT-PCR

  • Systems include Truenat and CBNAAT (Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test, e.g., GeneXpert).
  • Widely accessible
  • Turnaround Time: Quick results in 30-60 minutes.
  • Automation: Fully automated with minimal handling, reducing biosafety hazards.
  • Gene Targets:
    • CBNAAT: E gene for screening, N2 gene for confirmation.
    • Truenat: E gene for screening, RdRp gene for confirmation.
  • Disadvantages: Limited to 1-4 samples per run, suitable for low sample loads (24-48 samples/day).

Antigen Detection

  • Rapid chromatographic immunoassay (SD Biosensor) for qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein.
  • Sample Collection: Nasopharyngeal swab immersed in viral extraction buffer to inactivate the virus and release the antigen.
  • Point-of-Care Testing: Conducted at the bedside within one hour; antigen stability is limited to one hour.
  • Performance: Highly specific (99–100%) but moderate sensitivity (50–84%); symptomatic but negative patients should be referred for RT-PCR testing.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect

questions.text: What is the underlying factor responsible for inducing aplastic crisis in individuals with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
 
 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis (Option D):
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

Pox virus (Option A) is a large and complex virus known to cause two major diseases smallpox and molluscum contagiosum.

Epstein-Barr virus (Option B) (EBV) is a member of the herpesvirus family. EBV can cause majorly infectious mononucleosis, gastric carcinoma, Burkitt's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

Adenovirus (Option C) is known to cause various benign diseases like upper and lower respiratory tract infections, gastroenteritis in children, urinary tract infections, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text:
Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) life cycle:


	
		
			
			1) Accidental Host
			
			
			(a) Ardeid birds 
			
		
		
			
			2) Amplifier
			
			
			(b) Culex mosquitoes 
			
		
		
			
			3) Reservoir
			
			
			(c) Humans 
			
		
		
			
			4) Vector
			
			
			(d) Pigs
questions.solution:
Epidemiological features of Japanese encephalitis

Agent

Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV), Group B Arbovirus

Virus Family: Flaviviridae

Transmission Vector

Culex mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui)
 

Hosts

Pigs (Amplifier Host)

Ardeid Birds: Pond herons, Ducks, Poultry (Maintenance Host)

Man: (Accidental or dead-end host)

  • Do not develop high enough viremia to infect mosquitoes.
  • Primarily children (below 15 years), but all ages susceptible
  • No man-to-man transmission.

Horses: Only animals that can manifest symptoms (Option D).

Environmental Factors

Geographic Distribution:

  • Southeast Asia, East Asia, and the Western Pacific regions.
  • India
    • Endemic: To 21 states but mainly includes Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Haryana
  • Seasonal Distribution:
    • Monsoon and post-monsoon period (varies by region)

Other options are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses cannot integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HAV

Explanation:

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an RNA virus that causes acute liver infection but does not integrate into the host genome or cause cancer. Unlike other hepatitis viruses (such as HBV and HCV), HAV does not have a chronic phase and is not associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

HPV (Option A) Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus that primarily presents with cutaneous and mucosal lesions. High-risk HPV types, such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, are strongly associated with the development of cervical, anal, vulvar, vaginal, penile, and oropharyngeal cancers.

SV 40 (Option B) Simian vacuolating virus 40 is a Polyomavirus associated with mesothelioma. Large T antigen and small T antigen are the two viral oncoproteins that are expressed by SV 40 and can inactivate p53, RB, and PP2A, leading to malignancy.

EBV (Option D) Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is a herpesvirus that infects B lymphocytes and epithelial cells. EBV is associated with the development of several malignancies, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and some gastric cancers.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was performed. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Heterophile antibodies

Explanation:

Heterophile Antigens

  • Definition:
    • A type of hetero-antigen present in different species that share epitopes.
  • Cross-Reactivity:
    • Antibodies produced against an antigen from one species can react with the heterophile antigen from another species and vice versa
  • Diagnostic Applications:
    • Heterophile antigens are used in various serological tests to detect antibodies in patient serum.
    • Examples of Tests:
      • Weil-Felix Reaction: Used to diagnose certain infections, such as rickettsial infections.
      • Paul-Bunnell Test: Primarily used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.
      • Cold Agglutination Test: This test is used to detect specific antibodies that cause agglutination at low temperatures.
        • This test is primarily used to identify mycoplasma pneumonia.
      • Streptococcus MG Test: Used to detect antibodies associated with streptococcal infections.

Paul-Bunnell Test (Option C)

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Method:
    • Utilizes sheep red blood cells (RBCs) as antigens to detect heterophile antibodies in the patient’s serum.
  • Principle:
    • In infectious mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.
    • These antibodies can also occur after serum injections and in some normal individuals.
  • Procedure:
    • The inactivated serum is prepared by heating at 56°C for 30 minutes
    • The serum is mixed in doubling dilutions with an equal volume of a 1% sheep erythrocyte suspension.
    • Incubate at 37°C for 4 hours.
  • Interpretation:
    • Examine for agglutination.
    • An agglutination titer of 100 or above suggests infectious mononucleosis

Note: The Paul-Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes; the Monospot test, horse red cells.

Incorrect Options:

Complement fixation (Option A) is used to detect antigen-antibody reactions by assessing complement consumption. It is used in viral infections like influenza, syphilis, and fungal infections.

Superantigens (Option B) are proteins that cause excessive T-cell activation by bypassing normal antigen presentation. They are associated with toxic shock syndrome (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes)

Haptens (Option D) are small molecules that can trigger an immune response only when attached to a larger carrier protein. They play a role in drug allergies and some immune reactions.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • The virus shown in the picture is a DNA virus. In the above image, the virus first binds to the cell and enters inside the cell by uncoating.
  • After the entry of the virus inside the cell, three types of proteins, i.e., alpha, beta, and gamma, are formed via transcription and replication, which are pathognomonic of the herpes virus.
  • It has two cycles:
    • Lytic cycle: Immediate-early genes are expressed first, initiating the lytic life cycle of the virus, leading to the production of infectious virions and lysis of the host cell.
    • Latent cycle: There is limited gene expression and a lack of infectious virus particles.
  • Non- enveloped viruses

DNA

  • Adenovirus
  • Polyoma virus
  • Papovavirus
  • Picornavirus

  • Calicivirus
