  • Hepatitis E
  • Enveloped viruses
    • All other viruses except from above have an envelope, few of which are:

Incorrect Options:

Human Immunodeficiency Virus (Option A) It belongs to Retroviridae, which is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses.

Hepatitis B Virus (Option C) replication cycle involves the following steps: attachment and entry into hepatocytes, the release of the viral genome into the nucleus, conversion of the viral DNA into a covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA) form, transcription of viral genes, and replication of the viral genome, assembly of viral particles in the endoplasmic reticulum, and release through budding.

Coronavirus (Option D) It belongs to Coronaviridae, which is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enveloped ssRNA

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described - cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, bluish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots), and the development of a maculopapular rash - is highly suggestive of measles (also known as rubeola). Measles is caused by the measles virus, which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus.

Clinical Stages of Measles:

Stage

Duration

Symptoms

Incubation Period

10 days (up to 21 days)

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

Complications of Measles:

A. Secondary Bacterial Infections

  • Immune suppression following measles increases susceptibility to bacterial infections.
  • Otitis media and bronchopneumonia are the most frequent bacterial complications.
  • Worsening of underlying tuberculosis with a possible false-negative Mantoux test.

B. Complications Due to Measles Virus Itself

  • Giant-cell pneumonitis (Hecht’s pneumonia), primarily in immunocompromised and HIV-infected individuals.
  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup).
  • Diarrhea leading to malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency.

C. Central Nervous System (CNS) Complications

  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare but severe late complication characterized by progressive CNS deterioration.
  • Other CNS complications include post-measles encephalomyelitis and measles inclusion body encephalitis.

Incorrect Options:

Naked ssRNA (Option B): A virus with naked (non-enveloped) ssRNA does not fit the description of the measles virus. Naked ssRNA viruses, such as enteroviruses or hepatitis A virus, have different clinical presentations.

Naked dsRNA (Option C): There are no naked double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) viruses that cause symptoms like those seen in measles.

Enveloped dsRNA (Option D): Enveloped dsRNA viruses include the rotavirus (which causes gastroenteritis), but the clinical symptoms of rotavirus are not similar to measles.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L1

Explanation:

  • The HPV vaccine is made using recombinant L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles (VLPs) that mimic the HPV outer capsid. These VLPs elicit a strong immune response without containing viral genetic material, making the vaccine safe and effective.

Side Effects

Note:

  • Cervavac (HPV4) is licensed and recommended for both girls and boys in India, according to the recent guidelines by The Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) as of January 2024.
  • Cervarix (HPV2), on the other hand, was used previously and only licensed and recommended for girls in India, and not for boys.

Incorrect Options:

E6 & E7 (Option A): E6 and E7 are oncogenic proteins of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) that play a role in carcinogenesis by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins (p53 and Rb, respectively). These are not included in the HPV vaccine, as their presence could pose a risk of oncogenic transformation.

E1 & E2 (Option C): E1 and E2 are early proteins involved in HPV DNA replication and transcriptional regulation. They are not components of the HPV vaccine.

L2 (Option D): L2 is another capsid protein, but the HPV vaccine primarily uses the L1 protein to induce an immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Ebola virus is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transmitted by mosquito

Explanation:

Ebola virus is not transmitted by mosquitoes. Instead, it spreads through direct contact with infected bodily fluids (blood, saliva, vomit, feces, sweat, urine, breast milk, or semen) of symptomatic individuals or contaminated surfaces.

Incorrect Options:

It is a filovirus (Option A): Ebola virus belongs to the Filoviridae family, which also includes Marburg virus. Filoviruses are filamentous, enveloped, negative-sense RNA viruses that cause severe hemorrhagic fever.

Bats act as a reservoir (Option C): Fruit bats (Pteropodidae family) are believed to be the natural reservoirs of the Ebola virus, maintaining the virus in wildlife populations and occasionally transmitting it to other animals or humans.

Human-to-human transmission is seen (Option D): Ebola virus spreads between humans through direct contact with infected bodily fluids or contaminated objects. Healthcare workers and caregivers are at high risk if proper protective measures are not followed.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is employed to measure the viral load?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Real-time RT-PCR

Explanation:

Real-time Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) is the gold standard for measuring viral load, especially for RNA viruses like HIV, SARS-CoV-2, and HCV. It quantifies viral RNA in real-time, providing an accurate measure of infection severity and treatment response.

  • Real-time PCR, also known as quantitative PCR (qPCR), provides the advantage of quantifying DNA or RNA as the amplification process occurs in real time.
  • This is achieved by measuring the fluorescence emitted by DNA-binding dyes or probes that are incorporated during the PCR amplification.
  • Traditional PCR only allows for the detection of the PCR product at the end of the process, without the capability to quantify the initial amount of target nucleic acid.

Uses of Real-Time PCR:

  • Gene Expression Analysis
  • Quantification of DNA or RNA
  • Detection of Pathogens
  • Genotyping
  • Cancer Research
  • Forensic Analysis
  • Biotechnology Applications

Incorrect Options:

ELISA (Option A): Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) detects viral antigens or antibodies but does not quantify viral RNA or DNA. It is commonly used for screening infections like HIV and hepatitis but is not suitable for viral load measurement.

Western Blot (Option B): Western blot is a confirmatory test for detecting specific viral proteins, such as in HIV diagnosis. However, it does not quantify viral genetic material, making it unsuitable for viral load assessment.

Immunoelectrophoresis (Option D): Immunoelectrophoresis is used to separate and identify proteins (e.g., immunoglobulins in multiple myeloma) but does not measure viral load.

questions.text: Antibody testing for SARS-CoV-2 depends upon which of the following factors?

choices.text: That the patient is in the window period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Time of incubation

Explanation:

  • Antibody testing relies on the host's immune response, which takes time to develop.
  • IgM antibodies appear around 7–10 days after infection, while IgG antibodies become detectable after 2–3 weeks, peaking in the convalescent phase.
  • Thus, the timing of testing relative to symptom onset is critical.

Incorrect Options:

Presence of acute viral load (Option B): RT-PCR or antigen tests are used to detect acute viral load during early infection. Antibody tests do not detect active infection but indicate past exposure.

A high risk of reinfection (Option C): While waning immunity and viral mutations can contribute to reinfection, antibody testing does not directly assess reinfection risk.

That the patient is in the window period (Option D): The window period is the phase before detectable antibodies are produced. During this period, antibody tests may be falsely negative, making RT-PCR the preferred diagnostic method for early infection.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has the highest mortality once clinically manifested?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rabies

Explanation:

  • Among these, rabies has the highest case fatality rate (~100%) once symptoms appear, making it the most lethal of the listed diseases.
    • The virus infects the central nervous system (CNS), leading to encephalitis, paralysis, hydrophobia, and coma.
    • No effective treatment after symptom onset, but post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) with rabies vaccine + immunoglobulin is highly effective if given before symptoms develop.

 

Rabies virus

 

Epidemiological Determinants of Rabies:

Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family).
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission.
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet)
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands)

questions.text:
A patient presented with meningitis, a 4-day history of fever, and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel or tick bite. CSF findings showed:


	Increased protein
	Normal glucose
	Mild lymphocytosis
	Few RBCs


Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) West Nile virus

Explanation:

Enterovirus is the most common cause of viral (aseptic) meningitis,

  • The CSF profile suggests viral (aseptic) meningitis, characterized by:
    • Mild lymphocytosis (predominance of lymphocytes) → Viral etiology
    • Normal glucose → Bacterial meningitis usually causes low CSF glucose
    • Few RBCs → Suggests viral-induced microhemorrhages, often seen in West Nile virus (WNV) or Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Erythematous rash on the chest → Can be seen in viral infections

 

West Nile Virus (Option A): Flavivirus transmitted by mosquitoes (Culex species) but can occur without a travel history in endemic regions.

  • Causes viral meningoencephalitis with CSF lymphocytosis, normal glucose, and RBCs (due to microvascular hemorrhages).
  • Maculopapular rash (often on the chest) is a common feature.

Neisseria meningitidis (Option B): Causes bacterial meningitis, which presents with:

  • High neutrophils (not lymphocytes) in CSF
  • Low CSF glucose
  • Elevated protein
  • Rash is usually petechial (purpura fulminans), not a diffuse erythematous rash.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): Also causes bacterial meningitis with:

  • High neutrophils
  • Low glucose
  • No rash (rash is not a common feature).

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image, which causes microcephaly, is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Zika virus

Explanation:

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

The life cycle of Zika virus

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Incorrect Options:

Nipah virus (Option A): Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but is not known to cause congenital infections or microcephaly. Transmission occurs via direct contact with infected animals or person-to-person spread, not transplacental transmission.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option C): CMV is the most common congenital viral infection, but while it can cause microcephaly, it more frequently leads to sensorineural hearing loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and periventricular calcifications.

Rubella virus (Option D): Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) causes sensorineural deafness, cataracts, and congenital heart defects (PDA, pulmonary artery stenosis), but microcephaly is not a primary feature.

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tzanck cells

Explanation:

  • Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear are characteristic of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, particularly herpes genitalis.
  • The presence of painful genital lesions, along with a tingling sensation and burning pain preceding the appearance of ulcers, is highly suggestive of HSV infection.
  • The image shows multiple coalescing vesicles and erotions.
  • Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection caused primarily by HSV-2, although HSV-1 can also be responsible. It is characterised by the infection of genital skin or mucosa
  • Clinical features:
    • Multiple, painful, non-indurated vesicles that may rupture, forming coalescing vesicles or polycyclic erosions.
    • Bilateral tender lymphadenopathy is common.
    • Males: Painful penile ulcerations affecting the glans, prepuce and shaft of the penis
    • Females: Involves external genitalia, vulva, vagina and cervix. Accompanied by dysuria
  • Diagnosis: Tzanck smear, revealing multinucleated giant cells, a characteristic feature.
  • Serological testing, such as ELISA for HSV glycoprotein, can also aid in diagnosis.
  • Treatment typically involves antiviral medications : Acyclovir 200 mg 5 times a ( or Acyclo vir 400 mg TID) administered for 7-10 days for primary infection and 5 days for secondary infection.

Incorrect Options:

Pund cells (Option B): Pund cells are degenerated macrophages containing Donovan bodies, which are diagnostic for Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis) is a sexually transmitted bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, leading to painless genital ulcers.

Henderson–Patterson bodies (Option C): These intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies are found in Molluscum contagiosum, a poxvirus infection presenting as painless, dome-shaped umbilicated papules, rather than painful ulcers.

Guarnieri bodies (Option D): These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions are seen in smallpox (variola virus) and occasionally in vaccinia virus infections, which do not present as isolated painful genital ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis (JE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Man acts as the reservoir

Explanation:

Humans are not the primary reservoir hosts for the Japanese Encephalitis Virus.

The primary reservoirs are pigs and wading birds and humans are incidental hosts, meaning they can be infected but do not play a significant role in the transmission cycle because they do not produce enough virus in their blood to infect mosquitoes.

Epidemiological features of Japanese encephalitis

Agent

Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV), Group B Arbovirus

Virus Family: Flaviviridae

Transmission Vector

Culex mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui) (Option A ruled out)

Hosts

Pigs (Amplifier Host) (Option B ruled out)

Ardeid Birds: Pond herons, Ducks, Poultry (Maintenance Host)

Man: (Accidental or dead-end host)

  • Do not develop high enough viremia to infect mosquitoes.
  • Primarily children (below 15 years), but all ages susceptible
  • No man-to-man transmission.

Horses: Only animals that can manifest symptoms.

Environmental Factors

Geographic Distribution:

  • Southeast Asia, East Asia, and the Western Pacific regions.
  • India
    • Endemic: To 21 states but mainly includes Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Haryana
  • Seasonal Distribution:
    • Monsoon and post-monsoon period (varies by region)

Human is a dead-end host (Option D):Humans cannot transmit the virus further due to low viral load in the blood, making them a dead-end host.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cytomegalovirus

Explanation:

Viral infections are a major source of illness and death in patients after kidney transplantation. While cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent opportunistic virus affecting these recipients, many other viruses also influence patient outcomes.

Complications of immunosuppression in Renal Transplant

Infections

  • High Risk of Opportunistic Infections: Primarily caused by viruses.
  • Source of Infections: More commonly recipient-derived than donor-derived.
  • Bacterial Infections: Most prevalent within the first month post-transplant.
  • Viral Infections: Peak within the first 6 months post-transplantation. Most common- Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Preventative Measures: High-risk patients require chemoprophylaxis.
  • Vaccination: Pre-transplant immunization is recommended to protect against community-acquired infections.

Malignancy

  • Most Common Cancer: Skin cancer, specifically squamous cell carcinoma, is the most frequent malignancy in transplant recipients.
  • Increased Cancer Risks:
    • PTLD: Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder.
    • Kaposi Sarcoma: Increased incidence among transplant recipients.

Non-Immune Side Effects

  • Hypertension and Chronic Allograft Neuropathy: Typically associated with calcineurin inhibitors like Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus.
  • New-Onset Diabetes Mellitus: Often caused by steroids or Tacrolimus post-transplantation.
  • Elevated Risk of:
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Anemia
    • Cardiovascular Disease- leading cause of death among transplant survivors.

 

JC virus (Option B): Another polyomavirus, but primarily associated with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a severe CNS disease in immunocompromised patients. It does not significantly affect renal transplant function.

BK virus (Option C): Causes polyomavirus-associated nephropathy (PVAN), leading to renal dysfunction.

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) (Option D): Can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough for 5 days. Chest X-ray findings suggest the diagnosis. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Parainfluenza

Explanation:

  • The child’s barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and low-grade fever are characteristic of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).
  • Chest X-ray finding: "Steeple sign" (subglottic narrowing), a hallmark of croup.
  • Croup is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza virus (types 1 and 2 and 3).

Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

Refers to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper Respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea,
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Mild cough,
  • Low-grade fever.

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough,
  • Hoarseness,
  • Inspiratory stridor,
  • Fever may reach 39-40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent.
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright.
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week.

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice,
  • Coryza,
  • Normal to moderately inflamed pharynx.
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate.
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment.
  • Mild croup: Single dose dexamethasone.
  • Moderate to severe croup: Nebulized epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Used for moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress and hypoxia.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
    • Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg single dose; as low as 0.15 mg/kg may be effective.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

 

Incorrect Options:

Moraxella (Option A): Causes otitis media and sinusitis, not croup. Not associated with stridor or the steeple sign.

Ebola virus (Option C): Causes viral hemorrhagic fever with bleeding, high fever, and multiorgan failure. Does not cause croup or inspiratory stridor.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option D): Can cause bacterial tracheitis, which presents with high fever, toxic appearance, and purulent secretions. Not the most common cause of croup-like symptoms in children.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aedes aegypti

Explanation:

  • Zika virus is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes, especially Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.
  • These mosquitoes are day-biters, with peak activity during early morning and late afternoon.

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

The life cycle of Zika virus

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Phlebotomus (Option D): Transmits Leishmania spp. (causing leishmaniasis), not Zika virus. These are sandflies, different from mosquitoes.

questions.text: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by
questions.solution:
​Correct Answer: D) Virus

Explanation:

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus (Molluscum contagiosum virus) and presents as flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules with a characteristic central umbilication.

Poxviruses

Poxviruses are the largest viruses that infect vertebrates.

Morphology

  • Poxviruses measure approximately 400 nm in length and 230 nm in diameter, making them visible under a light microscope.
  • Poxviruses are typically brick-shaped or ellipsoid.
  • They possess an envelope consisting of two lipoprotein membranes (outer and inner), and the outer membrane features ridges.
  • The envelope encases a core, along with two structures of unknown function known as lateral bodies.
  • The core or nucleocapsid is biconcave and shaped like a dumbbell.
  • Poxviruses contain a single linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome.
  • They are unique among DNA viruses for replicating in the cytoplasm.

Human-Important poxviruses
  • Variola is the causative agent of smallpox, the first disease to be eradicated globally.
  • Vaccinia: Used as a vaccine for smallpox.
  • Molluscum contagiosum Virus: Causes warty lesions known as molluscum contagiosum.

Genera classification

  • Orthopoxvirus: Smallpox, monkeypox, vaccinia.
  • Molluscipoxvirus: Molluscum contagiosum.
  • Parapoxvirus: Milker’s nodules, bovine papular stomatitis viruses, etc.
  • Capripoxvirus: Sheeppox, goatpox, lumpy skin disease, etc.
  • Avipoxvirus: Fowlpox, pigeon pox, etc.
  • Leporipoxvirus: Myxoma, hare fibroma, etc.
  • Suipoxvirus: Swinepox virus.
  • Yatapoxvirus: Tanapox, Yabapox viruses.

 

Molluscum contagiosum

Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions.

Clinical manifestations

Lesions:

  • Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center.
  • Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles.
  • Lesions are umbilicated.
  • Genital lesions are commonly observed in adults.
  • Lesions typically resolve on their own within 3–4 months.

Transmission

  • Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools).
  • Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults.

Laboratory diagnosis

Molluscum bodies:

  • Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains.

Confirmation methods:

  • Electron microscopy
  • PCR

Cultivation:

  • The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals.

Treatment
  • Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.


Options A, B, & C are incorrect. Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a virus (Poxvirus). ​​

questions.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is associated with which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Epstein-Barr virus

Explanation:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the causative agent of oral hairy leukoplakia, which presents as white, corrugated wart like growths of epithelial tissue on the lateral tongue, commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.

Cytomegalovirus (Option A): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause oral ulcers in immunocompromised individuals but does not lead to oral hairy leukoplakia, which is specifically linked to Epstein-Barr virus.

Human Papilloma Virus (Option B): Human papilloma virus (HPV) is associated with oral warts and squamous papillomas rather than the white, corrugated lesions seen in oral hairy leukoplakia.

Herpes Simplex 1 Virus (Option C): Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) typically causes painful oral ulcers or cold sores but does not cause the characteristic painless, non-removable white patches of oral hairy leukoplakia.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses are associated with the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - EBV

Explanation:

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is strongly linked to the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It is a member of the herpesvirus family and is found to be associated with the endemic form of NPC, particularly in Southeast Asia. EBV infection can cause genetic changes in the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx, contributing to the development of cancer.

Malignancies associated with EBV:

Types of malignancy

Examples

Carcinoma

  • Gastric carcinoma (most common)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Lymphoma

 
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma (most common lymphocyte depletion and mixed cellularity)
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
    • Burkitt’s lymphoma
    • DLBCL (diffuse large B cell lymphoma)
    • Post-transplant lymphoma
    • T or NK cell lymphoma

Sarcoma

  • Leiomyosarcoma

Incorrect Options:

Adenovirus (Option A): While adenoviruses can cause respiratory and other infections, they are not strongly associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Herpes virus (Option C): This is a broad family of viruses, but EBV is the herpesvirus specifically associated with NPC. Not all herpesviruses are linked to this cancer.

Papillomavirus (Option D): HPV (Human papillomavirus) is more closely linked to cancers like cervical cancer, oral cancer, and head and neck cancers, but not to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: Receptor used for the entry of HIV virus into the host cell is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - CCR5

Explanation:

CCR5 (C-C chemokine receptor type 5) is one of the primary receptors used by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) to enter host cells. Specifically, CCR5 is found on the surface of CD4+ T cells and other immune cells, and HIV binds to it along with CD4 (another receptor) in order to gain entry into the host cell.

Modes of Transmission of HIV

  • Sexual Transmission:
    • Most common (75% of cases).
    • Heterosexual Route: Male to female via vaginal intercourse is typical; risk per encounter is low (0.1–1%). Higher risk with anal intercourse.
  • Blood Transfusion: Least common (5% of cases) but has a high transmission risk (90–95%).
  • Percutaneous/Mucosal Transmission: Includes needle stick injuries and sharing razors; less effective compared to sexual transmission.
  • Perinatal Transmission: 20–40% risk of mother-to-fetus transmission without intervention; highest risk during delivery.
  • Casual Contact: No evidence of transmission through casual contact, kissing, or insect bites.
  • Viral Load: Highest in blood, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal fluid; minimal in saliva and other body fluids.
  • Saliva: Contains substances that may inhibit HIV transmission.

Pathogenesis:

  • Receptor Attachment
    • Main Receptor:
      • HIV binds its gp120 to the CD4 receptor on host cells, primarily expressed on helper T cells and other cells like monocytes and macrophages.
    • Co-Receptors: Fusion requires a second receptor:
      • CXCR4: Found on T lymphocytes.
      • CCR5: Present on macrophage lineage cells. (Option B)
    • DC-SIGN:
      • A dendritic cell-specific receptor that binds HIV-1 but does not mediate entry; facilitates transport to lymphoid organs.
    • CCR5 Delta 32 Mutation:
      • Mutation can block HIV entry:
        • Homozygous individuals are resistant to HIV (1% of Northern Europeans).
        • Heterozygous individuals may have delayed progression to AIDS (10–15% of Europeans).
  • Replication

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are not used as a receptor for the entry of HIV into the host cells.

questions.text: What is the vector responsible for transmitting the Zika virus among the options listed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Aedes albopictus

Explanation:

  • Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is one of the primary vectors responsible for transmitting the Zika virus. This mosquito species, along with Aedes aegypti, plays a major role in the spread of Zika, as well as other viral infections like dengue and chikungunya.

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Mark the false statement regarding testing of covid 19:

choices.text: Most predominant method of diagnosis of Covid 19 is RT-PCR
First line screening assay: N gene assay
Peripheral ground glass opacities on CT are frequently observed.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - First Line Screening Assay: N Gene Assay:

  • The first-line screening assay for COVID-19 is typically the RdRp gene assay, not the N gene assay.
  • The RdRp gene is commonly targeted in molecular diagnostic tests for SARS-CoV-2 due to its high specificity and sensitivity in detecting the virus.

  • N (nucleocapsid) gene assay is used in many COVID-19 diagnostic tests and is a crucial component of the testing process. However, it's often used as a confirmatory or secondary assay rather than the primary screening assay.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Most Predominant Method of Diagnosis of COVID-19 is RT-PCR: Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) is indeed the most common method for diagnosing COVID-19. RT-PCR is highly sensitive and specific for detecting viral RNA, allowing for accurate diagnosis even at low viral loads

Option C - Confirmatory Assay: RdRp gene assay: The RdRp gene assay is used as a confirmatory test in COVID-19 diagnosis.

Option D - Peripheral ground glass opacities on CT are frequently observed.​​​  Ground glass opacities on CT scan are commonly seen in COVID-19, although they are not exclusive to this infection.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient, such as one with HIV/AIDS, presents with dysphagia and odynophagia. On upper GI endoscopy, white plaques are seen over the esophageal mucosa. A biopsy is taken for microscopic examination. What is the most likely finding on microscopy?

choices.text: Multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Yeast cells with pseudohyphae

Explanation:

  • An immunocompromised patient, such as one with HIV/AIDS, presenting with dysphagia, odynophagia, and white plaques on esophageal endoscopy, is showing classic signs of esophageal candidiasis, most commonly caused by Candida albicans; microscopic examination (via biopsy or KOH prep) typically reveals diagnostic yeast cells with pseudohyphae.

CDC-AIDS defining conditions:

  • Candidiasis of the bronchi, trachea, oesophagal or lungs. (Option A)
  • Cryptosporidiosis with diarrhoea (for longer than 1 month)
  • Cytomegalovirus disease (other than liver, spleen, or nodes), beginning when older than one month
  • Herpes simplex: chronic ulcers (lasting longer than 1 month); or bronchitis, pneumonitis, or esophagitis (beginning when older than one month)
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Lymphoma, primary, of brain
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (type of bacterial infection) or M. kansasii, disseminated or extrapulmonary
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Toxoplasmosis of the brain, beginning when older than one month

Acid-fast bacilli (Option B) are typically associated with infections caused by Mycobacterium species, such as tuberculosis or Mycobacterium avium complex. Their clinical presentation and diagnostic approach differ significantly; diagnosis relies on acid-fast staining of tissue or bodily fluids, rather than endoscopic findings of white esophageal plaques, which are more characteristic of fungal infections like candidiasis.

Branching septate hyphae at a 45-degree angle (Option C) is a hallmark of Aspergillus species, a type of mold that most commonly infects the lungs or sinuses, especially in immunocompromised individuals. Additionally, when Aspergillus does infect mucosal tissues, it does not produce the white plaque-like lesions seen in esophageal candidiasis.

Multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions (Option D) are classic histological findings in Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) esophagitis, another opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents with multiple small, well-defined "punched-out" ulcers in the esophagus, not the white, plaque-like lesions characteristic of Candida albicans.

questions.text: Which is the most common HPV serotype associated with cervical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPV types 16 and 18

Explanation:

HPV types 16 and 18 are the most common HPV serotypes associated with cervical carcinoma.

Types of HPV

 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis

 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Clinically, HPV are divided into 2 types:
    • Low risk HPV (6 & 11) cause nearly all genital warts, laryngeal papillomas and are rarely oncogenic. (Option B ruled out)
    • High risk HPV (16 & 18) cause approximately 95% of cervical cancers. HPV 16 is the most oncogenic in high risk HPV types. (Option A)

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5 , 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11).
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others (16 and 18 m/c)
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text:
Which of the following causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis:


	Polio virus
	Coxsackie A
	Coxsackie B
	Enterovirus 70
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 3,4

Explanation:

Acute Hemorrhagic Conjunctivitis

  • A highly contagious eye infection characterized by conjunctival redness, swelling, pain, photophobia, and subconjunctival hemorrhages.
  • It is caused by specific viral pathogens that can spread rapidly in crowded settings.
  • Pathogens: Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A
  • Occurs in the pandemic form of violent inflammatory conjunctivitis
  • Clinical Features:
    • Lacrimation
    • Photophobia
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Enlarged preauricular lymph nodes
    • Cornea is usually affected

Non-viral agents of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis:

  1. Pneumococci
  2. Neisseria species
  3. Haemophilus species
  4. Chlamydia

Polio virus (Option 1) RNA virus, belonging to family Picornavirus, under genera Enterovirus, usually affecting the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, causing either an inapparent infection, abortive poliomyelitis, paralytic poliomyelitis or non-paralytic poliomyelitis. It does not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis

Coxsackie B virus (Option 3) RNA virus, belonging to family Picornavirus, under genera Enterovirus, Epidemic myalgia or pleurodynia, also known as Bornholm disease, Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn, Juvenile diabetes, Orchitis, post-viral fatigue syndrome. Transplacental and neonatal transmission causes a serious disseminated disease that may in

questions.text: What is the vector responsible for transmitting the Zika virus among the options listed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aedes albopictus

Explanation:

  • Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is one of the primary vectors responsible for transmitting the Zika virus. This mosquito species, along with Aedes aegypti, plays a major role in the spread of Zika, as well as other viral infections like dengue and chikungunya.

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

The life cycle of Zika virus

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Receptor used for the entry of HIV virus into the host cell is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CCR5

Explanation:

  • CCR5 (C-C chemokine receptor type 5) is one of the primary receptors used by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) to enter host cells. Specifically, CCR5 is found on the surface of CD4+ T cells and other immune cells, and HIV binds to it along with CD4 (another receptor) in order to gain entry into the host cell.

Modes of Transmission of HIV

  • Sexual Transmission:
    • Most common (75% of cases).
    • Heterosexual Route: Male to female via vaginal intercourse is typical; risk per encounter is low (0.1–1%). Higher risk with anal intercourse.
  • Blood Transfusion: Least common (5% of cases) but has a high transmission risk (90–95%).
  • Percutaneous/Mucosal Transmission: Includes needle stick injuries and sharing razors; less effective compared to sexual transmission.
  • Perinatal Transmission: 20–40% risk of mother-to-fetus transmission without intervention; highest risk during delivery.
  • Casual Contact: No evidence of transmission through casual contact, kissing, or insect bites.
  • Viral Load: Highest in blood, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal fluid; minimal in saliva and other body fluids.
  • Saliva: Contains substances that may inhibit HIV transmission.

Pathogenesis:

  • Receptor Attachment
    • Main Receptor:
      • HIV binds its gp120 to the CD4 receptor on host cells, primarily expressed on helper T cells and other cells like monocytes and macrophages.
    • Co-Receptors: Fusion requires a second receptor:
      • CXCR4: Found on T lymphocytes.
      • CCR5: Present on macrophage lineage cells. (Option B)
    • DC-SIGN:
      • A dendritic cell-specific receptor that binds HIV-1 but does not mediate entry; facilitates transport to lymphoid organs.
    • CCR5 Delta 32 Mutation:
      • Mutation can block HIV entry:
        1. Homozygous individuals are resistant to HIV (1% of Northern Europeans).
        2. Heterozygous individuals may have delayed progression to AIDS (10–15% of Europeans).
  • Replication

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are not used as a receptor for the entry of HIV into the host cells.

questions.text: What is the most likely causative agent for a Tzanck smear showing multinucleated cells?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • A positive Tzanck smear demonstrates multinucleated giant epithelial cells and is classically associated with herpetic infections — most commonly Herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck supports a herpesvirus family etiology (HSV or VZV), but HSV is the most frequent cause for localized herpetic lesions.

Varicella-zoster virus (Option A): Also a herpesvirus and can produce multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck; however, when asked “most likely” in a general context, HSV is the usual single best answer for a positive Tzanck smear.

Human papillomavirus (Option C): Causes koilocytosis — not multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck.

Coxsackievirus A16 (Option D): Causes HFMD; does not give a positive Tzanck smear.

questions.text: HPV infection is most commonly associated with which type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Oropharyngeal cancer

Explanation:

  • HPV (especially HPV-16) is strongly associated with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (tonsil, base of tongue) and is a major causative factor for a rising subset of oropharyngeal cancers.
  • HPV is also classically linked to cervical and anogenital cancers.

Types of HPV

 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis

 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Lung cancer (Option A): Primarily linked to smoking, radon, environmental factors; HPV is not a common cause.

Stomach cancer (Option C): Mainly associated with Helicobacter pylori and dietary/genetic factors.

Esophageal cancer (Option D): Risk factors include smoking, alcohol, Barrett’s oesophagus; HPV is not the typical cause.

questions.text: A woman was bitten by a rabid dog. The dog developed symptoms and died within a week. What is the best method for antemortem diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DFAT

Explanation:

  • The best method for antemortem diagnosis of rabies is the DFAT (Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test).
  • In suspected rabies before death, the aim is to detect rabies virus antigen in accessible tissues/fluids.

DFAT is the gold standard antemortem test:

  • Uses fluorescent-labelled antibodies specific for rabies virus.
  • Can be done on corneal smears, nuchal skin biopsy (hair follicles), or saliva.
  • Gives rapid, sensitive, and specific results.

Detection of Negri bodies (Option A): Negri bodies (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons) are seen on histology of infected brain tissue. This is a postmortem finding, not antemortem.

Seller’s staining (Option C): Seller’s stain highlights Negri bodies in brain tissue. This is a postmortem confirmation method.

Brain biopsy (Option D): Invasive, rarely done for antemortem rabies diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was admitted with pneumonia. The microscopy shows the following image. Choose the correct organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Influenza

Explanation:

  • The given structure is identified on the basis of the enveloped, 8 segmented RNA virus, which is found in Influenza virus.

Classification:

  • Family: Orthomyxoviridae

  • Type: Enveloped virus
  • Genome: Segmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA (–ssRNA)
  • Segments: 8 separate RNA segments (in influenza A and B; C has 7)

A. Outer Envelope

  • Derived from host cell membrane during budding.
  • Contains two major glycoprotein spikes:
    • Hemagglutinin (HA)
      • Mediates viral attachment to host cells by binding sialic acid receptors.
      • Initiates membrane fusion during viral entry.
      • Target for neutralizing antibodies.
    • Neuraminidase (NA)
      • Cleaves sialic acid residues to release newly formed virions from infected cells.
      • Target for antiviral drugs (e.g., oseltamivir, zanamivir).
  • Envelope also contains M2 ion channel protein:
    • Important for uncoating of the virus by altering pH inside the virion.

B. Matrix Layer

  • Just beneath the envelope.
  • Matrix protein M1:
    • Provides structural stability.
    • Links the envelope to the ribonucleoprotein core.

C. Ribonucleoprotein Core

  • 8 separate negative-sense RNA segments.
  • Each RNA segment is bound to nucleoprotein (NP) and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase complex:
    • PB1, PB2, PA (polymerase basic proteins).
  • Segmented genome allows genetic reassortment → basis for antigenic shift.

Special Features:

  • Segmented genome (8 pieces) → enables exchange of segments between strains → major cause of pandemics.
  • Antigenic drift: Minor changes in HA and NA due to point mutations → seasonal epidemics.
  • Antigenic shift: Major change due to reassortment of genome segments → pandemics.

 

Rotavirus (Option B): Non eveloped, 11 segmented dsRNA virus.

Hepatitis virus (Option C): None of the hepatitis virus have segmented genome. HAV (+ssRNA, non-enveloped), HBV (partially dsDNA, enveloped), HCV (+ssRNA, enveloped), HDV (–ssRNA, enveloped).

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Option D): Enveloped, non-segmented ssRNA virus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was admitted with fever, headache and retro-orbital pain with rash. The tourniquet test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dengue hemorrhagic fever

Explanation:

  • A young adult with the classic triad of fever, headache and retroorbital pain, along with rash and positive tourniquet test, suggests that the patient has acquired dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Pathophysiology in DHF

  • Caused by secondary infection with a different dengue virus serotype (DENV-1 to DENV-4).
  • Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) leads to:
    • Increased vascular permeability.
    • Plasma leakage → hypotension/shock (Dengue shock syndrome).
    • Thrombocytopenia and bleeding tendencies.

Malaria (Option A): Presents with cyclical fevers, chills, anemia, splenomegaly.

Measles (Option B): Fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, rash starting at hairline → spreads downwards. No history of retro-orbital pain, no positive tourniquet test.

Japanese encephalitis (Option D): Arboviral disease with fever, headache, altered sensorium, seizures.

questions.text: A young adult presents with facial pain and painful vesicular lesions in the mouth. Tzanck smear reveals multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1, more commonly for orofacial lesions) causes painful vesicular eruptions on the lips, gums, or oral mucosa, often preceded by a prodrome of tingling or burning.
  • On Tzanck smear (scraping from the base of a vesicle), HSV-infected keratinocytes fuse to form multinucleated giant cells.
  • The nuclei show Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions — eosinophilic bodies representing viral replication centers.

Adenovirus (Option A) typically causes respiratory tract infections and conjunctivitis but does not produce vesicular oral lesions or multinucleated giant cells .

Cytomegalovirus (Option B) infections cause “owl’s eye” intranuclear inclusions but generally do not present with vesicular lesions in the mouth .

Epstein-Barr virus (Option D) is associated with infectious mononucleosis and oral hairy leukoplakia, but not painful vesicular lesions or giant cell formation .

questions.text: A patient is positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute hepatitis

Explanation: A patient positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM points toward Acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HSV

Explanation: A Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells is characteristic of Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.

Microscopic Features of the Herpes Virus:

Herpes Simplex Virus:

  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
  • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8):

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

HIV (Option A) does not cause multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear; it is diagnosed with serological tests (e.g., ELISA, Western blot) or PCR.

HPV (Option C) is associated with koilocytes (perinuclear halos in epithelial cells), not multinucleated giant cells.

EBV (Option D) is associated with Downey cells, which are atypical lymphocytes with a ballerina skirt appearance, seen in peripheral blood smears. Diagnosed using the Monospot test or serology, not a Tzanck smear.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HBsAg + HBe

Explanation: The correct marker for Infectious Hepatitis B is HBsAg + HBe, as HBsAg indicates active infection, and HBeAg signifies high infectivity.
