questions.text: A PLHIV came with multiple dog bites with a punctured wound. Choose the correctmanagement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Local Treatment + RIG + Vaccine

Explanation: For a PLHIV with category III dog bites (multiple deep wounds), the correct management is local treatment, Rabies Immune Globulin (RIG), and the rabies vaccine.

Management of Dog Bite:

Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I
  • Touching or feeding animals
  • Licking of intact skin
  • Ensure proper hygiene
  • No treatment required

Category II
  • Nibbling on uncovered skin
  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding
  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

Rabies vaccination:

  • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14
  • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3
  • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III
  • Bites or scratches with bleeding
  • Licks on broken skin
  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)
  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.
  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.
  • Rabies vaccination:
    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14
    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3
  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):
    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

Required for unvaccinated individuals

Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles in the genital region. Identify the lesion shown in the image and choose the correct diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Herpes:

  • Bilateral painful vesicles, along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, are seen in HSV-2 infection.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chancroid: Chancroid causes painful ulcers but typically presents as a single, larger ulcer with ragged edges, not multiple vesicles.

Option C - Syphilis: Syphilis causes painless genital ulcers.

Option D - Candidiasis: Candidiasis does not cause painful vesicular lesions.

questions.text: Parvo B19 associated with all except?

choices.text: Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aplastic anemia in immunocompromised:

  • Persistent pure red cell aplasia in immunocompromised is associated with Parvo B-19 virus not Aplastic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fever with petechial rash:

  • Parvo B19 virus is associated with Erythema infectiosum which presents with macular erythematous rash present on the cheek

Option B - Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia:

  • Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia is associated with Parvo B-19 virus.

Option D - Hydrops fetalis:

  • Hydrops fetalis is associated with Parvo B-19 virus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases
The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure:

  • Antigenic drift is a phenomenon that occurs in influenza viruses. It involves a gradual sequential change in the antigenic structure of the virus due to mutations in the genes that code for its surface proteins. 
  • These surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) are responsible for the recognition and binding of the virus to host cells and the release of newly formed virus particles from infected cells, respectively.
  • The accumulation of these mutations in the HA and NA genes over time can lead to the emergence of new strains. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases: This is inaccurate because antigenic drift is less likely to cause major epidemics and pandemics.

Option C - The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens: The new antigens formed due to antigenic drift are related to the previous antigens, so they react with antisera to the predecessor virus strains to varying degrees.

Option D - Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses still provide some degree of cross-protection against the new variants, but the degree of protection may vary depending on the degree of antigenic similarity between the old and new strains.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza ?

choices.text: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine is used
5-12 years is a high risk group

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5-12 years is a High Risk Group:

  • The high-risk groups for severe complications of influenza typically include young children (especially those under 2 years), the elderly (65 years and older), pregnant women, individuals with underlying health conditions, and immunocompromised individuals. The age group of 5-12 years is generally considered to have a lower risk compared to these high-risk groups.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intranasal Live attenuated vaccine is used: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine, a trivalent vaccine H1N1 (A), H3N2 (A), type B is indicated for individuals with influenza infection, contraindicated in low immunity.

Option C - Aquatic birds act as reservoir: Aquatic birds, particularly wild waterfowl, are considered the natural reservoir for influenza viruses. They can carry different strains of influenza viruses, including avian influenza viruses, without showing symptoms. These viruses can occasionally cross over to infect other species, including humans.

Option D - Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: The secondary attack rate refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to an infected individual. In the case of influenza, the secondary attack rate can vary depending on factors such as the specific strain, population density, and level of immunity. Generally, the secondary attack rate for influenza is estimated to be around 5 to 15%.

questions.text: Koplik spots are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Measles:

  • Koplik spots are pathognomonic features characterized by small, white-colored bumps on the erythematous base that appear in the mouth in the prodromal stage of measles.
  • Prodromal phase of measles
    • Fever - 1st manifestation around 10th day.
    • 3 C's - Cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.
    • Pathognomonic feature - Kopliks spot near molar appears after 2 days of fever.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Koplik spots are not seen in these conditions.

questions.text: Identify the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hantavirus:

  • Hantavirus is a single-stranded RNA virus responsible for causing Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. The main target site for Hantavirus is the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Influenza Virus: Influenza is caused by Orthomyxovirus and is a single-stranded RNA virus. It has neuraminidase and hemagglutinin spike proteins.

Option C - Adenovirus: It is a double-stranded DNA virus that is responsible for causing respiratory illness.

Option D - None of the Above: This option cannot be the answer since the Hantavirus is an organism shown in the picture.

questions.text: Antemortem diagnosis of rabies is made with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Corneal Impression Smear:

  • The antemortem diagnosis of rabies is challenging as it requires specialized laboratory techniques.
  • Antemortem diagnosis of rabies can be made by rabies antigen detection by performing a corneal impression smear, skin biopsy from the nape of the neck containing at least 10 hair follicles, and saliva. The viral antigens are present in these preparations and are examined for their presence using techniques like direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) testing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rabies Virus Specific Antibodies: While the presence of rabies virus-specific antibodies can indicate a past infection or immune response, it is not a reliable method for antemortem diagnosis. Antibodies may take time to develop and may not be detectable during the early stages of infection.

Option B - Inoculation in Cell Lines: Inoculation of samples in cell lines is a method used for viral isolation and growth but is not commonly used for antemortem diagnosis of rabies. It is a time-consuming process and requires specific laboratory facilities.

Option C - Negri Bodies in Hippocampus: Negri bodies are characteristic microscopic inclusion bodies found in certain neurons of the central nervous system affected by rabies virus infection. However, their detection usually requires brain tissue examination postmortem (after death) and is not feasible for antemortem diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following virus is from Herpes virus family?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - EBV: 

  • EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) EBV, also known as Human herpesvirus 4 (HHV-4), is a member of the Herpesviridae family. It is associated with infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever) and is also linked to several other diseases, including certain cancers, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Other members of Herpesviridae are

Type

Virus

Associated Diseases

HHV1

Herpes Simplex Virus 1

Oral herpes (cold sores), genital herpes, and encephalitis.

HHV2

Herpes Simplex Virus 2

Genital herpes.

HHV3

Herpes Zoster Virus

Chickenpox and shingles.

HHV4

Epstein–Barr virus

Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

HHV5

Cytomegalovirus (largest member)

Congenital infections, mononucleosis, organ transplant complications.

HHV6

Human Herpesvirus 6

Roseola infantum, febrile illness

HHV7

Human Herpesvirus 7

Febrile illness and a few cases of roseola infantum

HHV8

Human Herpesvirus 8

Kaposi's sarcoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rubella: Rubella is caused by the Rubella virus, which belongs to the Togaviridae family, not the Herpesviridae family.

Option B - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, is caused by the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. 

Option C - Rabies: Rabies is caused by the Rabies virus, which belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family.

questions.text: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Poxvirus:

  • Molluscum contagiosum is caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV), which belongs to the Poxvirus family.
  • MCV infects the skin and mucous membranes, resulting in the formation of small, flesh-colored, or pinkish bumps with a central indentation. These bumps are typically painless and may resolve on their own over time.
  • Other members of poxvirus are the variola virus, causing smallpox, and the vaccinia virus, causing chicken pox.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Adenovirus: Adenovirus is a group of human adenovirusesA to F that can cause respiratory infections, and conjunctivitis.

Option B - Flavivirus: Flaviviruses are a family of viruses including dengue virus, zika virus, and yellow fever virus.

Option C - Rubivirus: Rubivirus refers to the Rubella virus, which causes Rubella (German measles).

questions.text: SSPE is a complication of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Measles:

  • SSPE (Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis) is a rare, slowly progressive neurological disorder that occurs as a late complication of measles virus infection.
  • It occurs many years after measles, around 7- 13 years. But once it occurs, within 1-3 years, it becomes fatal.
  • It manifests as progressive deterioration of motor and cognitive functions, focal/generalized seizures, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. SSPE is not a complication of these viruses.

questions.text: Which subtype of human papilloma virus has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HPV 16 & 18:

  • High-risk subtypes of human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV 16 and HPV 18, are known to have the highest association with the development of cervical carcinoma.
  • Other high-risk human papillomaviruses associated with cervical carcinoma are HPV 31, 33, and 35.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HPV 6 & 11: HPV 6 and HPV 11 are classified as low-risk subtypes and are commonly associated with condyloma acuminatum and laryngeal papillomatosis.

Option C - HPV 31 & 32: HPV 31 is a high-risk subtype associated with cervical cancer, but HPV 32 is not associated with cervical carcinoma.

Option D - HPV 1 & 2: HPV 1 and HPV 2 are low-risk subtypes associated with plantar warts/verruca and filiform warts.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Parvovirus B19: 

Parvovirus B19 infection is known to cause a condition called “fifth disease” or erythema infectiosum. In some cases, Parvovirus B19 can lead to a transient aplastic crisis in a patient with an underlying hemolytic condition and hydrops fetalis, which mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. The virus infects erythroid progenitor cells, leading to temporary suppression of red blood cell production. Parvovirus B19 is, therefore, a viral infection that mimics erythroblastosis fetalis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV infection is primarily associated with oral or genital ulcers, and it does not typically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

Option B - Epstein-Barr Virus: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. Although EBV can cause abnormal liver function and anemia, it does not specifically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

Option C - Picornavirus: Picornaviruses are a large family of viruses that include common viruses such as rhinoviruses and enteroviruses. While certain picornaviruses can cause mild respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms, they do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Herpes simplex:

Inclusion Bodies and Viruses Producing Them

Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

  • Negri bodies – rabies virus
  • Paschen body – variola virus
  • Guamieri bodies – vaccinia virus
  • Bollinger bodies – fowlpox virus
  • Molluscum bodies – molluscum contagiosum virus
  • Perinuclear cytoplasmic body – reovirus

Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

Cowdry type A inclusions

  • Torres body – yellow fever virus
  • Lipschutz body – herpes simplex virus

Cowdry type B inclusions

  • Poliovirus
  • Adenovirus

Intracytoplasmic and Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

  • Owl’s eye appearance – cytomegalovirus
  • Measles virus

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Togavirus:

  • Rubella virus is classified as a Togavirus. Togaviruses are a family of enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. Rubella virus, also known as the German measles virus, belongs to the genus Rubivirus within the Togaviridae family.
  • Other viruses included in Togavirus are:
    • Chikungunya virus.
    • Western equine encephalitis virus.
    • Eastern equine encephalitis virus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Flavivirus: Flaviviruses are another family of RNA viruses and include viruses such as Japanese encephalitis, Yellow fever, Zika, Dengue, West Nile fever, and Hepatitis C.

Option C - Paramyxovirus: Paramyxoviruses are yet another family of RNA viruses known for causing respiratory infections such as respiratory syncytial virus measles, mumps, parainfluenza, and Nipah.

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: Orthomyxoviruses are a family of RNA viruses that include influenza viruses.

questions.text: Vaccine that require strain change due to evolving organism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Influenza:

  • Influenza is caused by influenza viruses, which have the ability to undergo frequent genetic changes through antigenic drift (seen in influenza A & B, point mutation occurs) and antigenic shift (seen in Influenza A, genetic reassotment occurs) .
  • This means that the viral strains circulating in the population can change over time, making the previously developed vaccines less effective against the new strains. Therefore, annual updates and strain changes are required in the influenza vaccine to ensure its effectiveness against the evolving strains.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Diphtheria: The diphtheria vaccine is based on the toxoid produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and does not require frequent strain changes.

Option C - Polio: The polio vaccine targets the poliovirus, and while there are different serotypes of the virus, the vaccine does not require frequent strain changes as the available vaccines offer protection against all known serotypes.

Option D - Typhoid: The typhoid vaccine is based on specific strains of Salmonella typhi bacteria and does not require frequent strain changes.

questions.text: During the period between 1 to 4 months following renal transplantation, which pathogen is most commonly responsible for infecting renal transplant recipients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cytomegalovirus:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV), is the predominant pathogen to infect renal (solid organ) transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following transplantation because of reactivation of the virus in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The immunosuppressive medications taken by transplant recipients increase their susceptibility to CMV infection, which can lead to significant morbidity and complications in the early post-transplant period.
  • It presents in various forms, such as:
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia, a life-threatening complication seen in 15–20% of bone marrow and solid organ transplant recipients
    • Febrile leukopenia is seen among solid organ transplant recipients.
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis in lung transplants.
    • Graft atherosclerosis in heart transplants.
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not the most common organism to cause infection in an organ transplant recipient between 1 to 4 months.

questions.text: What is the term used to refer to the antigen known as Australia antigen among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HBsAg:

  • The Australia antigen, also known as the Australia antigen marker, is represented by the HBsAg.
  • The presence of HBsAg in the blood indicates an active Hepatitis B infection. It is an important marker used for screening and diagnosis of Hepatitis B.

Structural proteins of HBV

Description

P – DNA Polymerase
  • Largest
  • Reverse transcriptase
  • RNAse

C – Core gene
  • Has a core area and a pre-core area
  • Core area coats for C antigen
  • Pre-core area codes for E antigen

S – Surface Antigen (Australia Antigen)
  • These have different sizes (Small, medium and large)

X – HBX responsible for carcinogenesis
  • Liver (Hepatocellular carcinoma)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HBeAg: HBeAg is another antigen produced by the Hepatitis B virus during active viral replication. Its presence indicates high viral replication and infectivity. HBeAg is used as a marker to assess the severity and prognosis of Hepatitis B infection.

Option C - HBcAg: Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is an antigen that is located in the inner core of the Hepatitis B virus.

Option D- HBX: HBX is an oncoprotein responsible for hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Corona virus is incorrect?

choices.text: Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike
Human corona virus 229 E is alpha type

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Icosahedral Capsid:

  • Coronavirus has a Helical capsid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ssRNA genome: Coronavirus is a single-stranded RNA virus. All RNA viruses have ssRNA genomes except Reoviridae (dsRNA)

Option C - Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike: Spreads primarily through respiratory droplets and aerosols. Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike protein to angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 receptor on cell membranes.

Option D - Human coronavirus 229E is an alpha-type: Human coronavirus 229E is indeed classified as an alpha-type coronavirus.

questions.text: Which of the following virus is from Herpes virus family?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - EBV:

  • EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) EBV, also known as Human herpesvirus 4 (HHV-4), is a member of the Herpesviridae family. It is associated with infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever) and is also linked to several other diseases, including certain cancers, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Other members of Herpesviridae are

Type

Virus

Associated Diseases

HHV1

Herpes Simplex Virus 1

Oral herpes (cold sores), genital herpes, and encephalitis.

HHV2

Herpes Simplex Virus 2

Genital herpes.

HHV3

Herpes Zoster Virus

Chickenpox and shingles.

HHV4

Epstein–Barr virus

Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

HHV5

Cytomegalovirus (largest member)

Congenital infections, mononucleosis, organ transplant complications.

HHV6

Human Herpesvirus 6

Roseola infantum, febrile illness

HHV7

Human Herpesvirus 7

Febrile illness and a few cases of roseola infantum

HHV8

Human Herpesvirus 8

Kaposi's sarcoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rubella: Rubella is caused by the Rubella virus, which belongs to the Togaviridae family, not the Herpesviridae family.

Option B - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, is caused by the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family.

Option C - Rabies: Rabies is caused by the Rabies virus, which belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who had a history of domestic animal bite has come for a follow-up post 90 days after receiving rabies post-exposure prophylaxis. Now what will you use for rapid diagnosis of rabies in this case?

choices.text: Skin biopsy with fluorescent antibody testing

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Skin Biopsy with Fluorescent Antibody Testing:

  • Skin biopsy for rabies antigen detection via direct fluorescent antibody testing is a commonly used method for rapid diagnosis of rabies. A skin biopsy sample taken from the nape of the neck with at least 10 hair follicles is the best specimen, and it is stained with fluorescent antibodies specific to the rabies virus. If the virus is present, it will bind to the antibodies and produce a fluorescence, confirming the diagnosis of rabies.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rabies Virus Specific Antibodies: Testing for rabies virus-specific antibodies in the patient's blood is not a suitable method for diagnosis of rabies. The presence of antibodies in blood appears late and is present in both rabies-infected and immunized individuals. CSF antibodies appear early, and they are produced only in rabies-infected individuals but not in response to vaccination

Option C - Inoculation in Mice: Inoculation in mice helps in the isolation of the virus. It involves injecting the patient's tissue sample into a live mouse and observing for signs of rabies infection in the mouse. This method is time-consuming and may not provide rapid results.

Option D - Corneal Impression Smear: Corneal impression smear is another method used for diagnosing rabies via direct fluorescent antibody testing, but with a low sensitivity of 30%.

questions.text: Which subtype of human papilloma virus has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HPV 16 & 18:

  • High-risk subtypes of human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV 16 and HPV 18, are known to have the highest association with the development of cervical carcinoma.
  • Other high-risk human papillomaviruses associated with cervical carcinoma are HPV 31, 33, and 35.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HPV 6 & 11: HPV 6 and HPV 11 are classified as low-risk subtypes and are commonly associated with condyloma acuminatum and laryngeal papillomatosis.

Option C - HPV 31 & 32: HPV 31 is a high-risk subtype associated with cervical cancer, but HPV 32 is not associated with cervical carcinoma.

Option D - HPV 1 & 2: HPV 1 and HPV 2 are low-risk subtypes associated with plantar warts/verruca and filiform warts.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anti HBc Ab:

  • Anti-HBcAb (Antibodies against Hepatitis B core antigen) is present during and after the acute phase of Hepatitis B infection. It persists in the serum even during recurrences and in individuals with chronic hepatitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is not detectable in the serum.

Option B - Anti HBs Ab: Antibodies against Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to Hepatitis B following vaccination.

Option D - HBe Ag: Hepatitis B pre-core antigen typically suggests the infectivity of the virus; presence of this antigen suggests high infectivity, and the absence suggests low infectivity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the influenza virus is false?

choices.text: Intranasal Live attenuated vaccine is used
5-12 years is a High Risk Group

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 5-12 years is a High Risk Group:

  • The high-risk groups for severe complications of influenza typically include young children (especially those under 2 years), the elderly (65 years and older), pregnant women, individuals with underlying health conditions, and immunocompromised individuals. The age group of 5-12 years is generally considered to have a lower risk compared to these high-risk groups.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Secondary Attack rate is 5-15%: The secondary attack rate refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to an infected individual. In the case of influenza, the secondary attack rate can vary depending on factors such as the specific strain, population density, and level of immunity. Generally, the secondary attack rate for influenza is estimated to be around 5 to 15%.

Option B - Intranasal Live Attenuated Vaccine is used: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine, a trivalent vaccine H1N1 (A), H3N2 (A), type B is indicated for individuals with influenza infection, contraindicated in low immunity.

Option D - Aquatic Birds act as Reservoir: Aquatic birds, particularly wild waterfowl, are considered the natural reservoir for influenza viruses. They can carry different strains of influenza viruses, including avian influenza viruses, without showing symptoms. These viruses can occasionally cross over to infect other species, including humans.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene:

  • Ganciclovir is a nucleoside DNA polymerase inhibitor an antiviral drug commonly used for the treatment of CMV infections. Resistance to ganciclovir can occur due to mutations in the UL97 and UL54 gene of CMV.
  • Ganciclovir is converted by viral phosphotransferase encoded by the CMV UL97 gene to form ganciclovir triphosphate that inhibits CMV DNA polymerase. Mutations in the UL97 gene can result in reduced phosphorylation of ganciclovir, leading to decreased efficacy of the drug and the development of resistance.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell: Human fibroblasts are the most specific and ideal cell lines for the isolation of the cytomegalovirus.

Option C - The commonest manifestation of CMV-associated disease is watery diarrhea: CMV is the most common infection associated with congenital defects. In Immunocompetent individuals, after transplantation, it causes mononucleosis-like disease, and in immunocompromised individuals (HIV/transplantation), it causes, most commonly, CMV retinitis. 

Option D - UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross-resistance to Foscarnet: UL54 refers to the DNA polymerase gene of CMV, which is the target of antiviral drugs like ganciclovir and foscarnet, and mutation in this gene can lead to resistance against ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is represented by the given form of replication ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Influenza Virus:

  • The correct choice for the given form of replication is the Influenza virus.
  • Influenza virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Its replication process involves several distinct steps:
    • Attachment: The spikes of hemagglutinin bind to sialic acid found on the surface of the host cell’s membrane.
    • Entry: The virus enters the host cell by endocytosis, which involves the engulfment of the virus particle by the cell membrane and the formation of a vesicle called an endosome.
    • Fusion: The viral envelope fuses with the endosomal membrane, and the M2 ion channel allows entry of H+ ions - H+ influx, resulting in uncoating and releasing the viral genetic material into the host cell's cytoplasm.
    • Replication: The viral RNA serves as a template for the synthesis of new viral RNA segments (turning negative sense RNA into positive sense RNA), as well as viral proteins. The viral RNA polymerase, which is carried by the virus, is responsible for replicating and transcribing the viral RNA.
    • Assembly: Newly synthesized viral RNA segments and proteins are assembled into new virus particles within the host cell.
    • Budding: The assembled virus particles bud from the host cell's plasma membrane, acquiring an envelope derived from the host cell membrane. This process allows the virus to be released by neuraminidase and potentially infect other cells.

Incorrect Options: 

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with diarrhea and vomiting for three days. Which of the following enterotoxins is most likely responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NSP4:

  • Diarrhea and vomiting in a 6-month-old child are commonly associated with viral gastroenteritis, particularly caused by rotavirus infection. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children worldwide.
  • Rotavirus produces several viral proteins, including enterotoxins, that contribute to the pathogenesis of gastroenteritis. Among these, NSP4 (Nonstructural Protein 4) is an enterotoxin primarily responsible for causing diarrhea by altering epithelial cell function and permeability.
  • Structural proteins of Rotavirus:
    • Structural protein: VP1-4, VP6, VP7.
    • Non-structural protein: NSP1-6.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - NSP6: NSP6 is another nonstructural protein produced by rotavirus. However, it is not primarily associated with causing diarrhea or vomiting in infected individuals.

Option C - VP3: VP3 is a structural protein of the rotavirus and is involved in the capping of the virus particle.

Option D - VP7: VP7 is another structural protein of the rotavirus, known as the glycoprotein, that forms the capsid layer of the virus.

questions.text: The association of human herpesvirus 8 is observed in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Adult T-cell Leukemia:

  • Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is not associated with Adult T-cell leukemia. Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1), a different virus belonging to the Retroviridae family.
  • Human herpesvirus 8, also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is a member of the herpesvirus family. It is primarily associated with certain malignancies and diseases, including:
    • Kaposi sarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma of vascular origin characterized by dark/violaceous plaques or nodules in immunocompromised individuals.
    • Primary effusion lymphoma: A rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the accumulation of lymphoma cells in body cavities, such as the pleural or peritoneal cavity.
    • Castleman disease: A rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by enlarged lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:
Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which type of infection is more likely to occur following the transfusion of Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma, given its ability to destroy lipid-enveloped viruses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hepatitis A Virus (HAV):

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection is likely to occur with transfusion of solvent/detergent (SD) plasma. Solvent/detergent treatment is a method used to inactivate lipid-enveloped viruses in plasma products. It involves the use of organic solvents and detergents to disrupt the lipid envelope of viruses, rendering them non-infectious. This treatment method is effective against lipid-enveloped viruses.
  • Non-enveloped DNA viruses - parvovirus, adenovirus and papovavirus
  • Non-enveloped RNA viruses - picornavirus, reovirus, calicivirus, hepatitis A virus, and hepatitis E virus.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are enveloped viruses that can be destroyed by the solvent/detergent method.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - RNA:

  • Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to study gene expression by detecting and analyzing mRNA. It involves the separation of RNA molecules based on their size using gel electrophoresis, followed by their transfer onto a solid support membrane (usually nylon or nitrocellulose). The transferred RNA molecules are then immobilized on the membrane.
  • To detect specific RNA molecules, the membrane is hybridized with a labeled nucleic acid probe that is complementary to the target RNA sequence of interest. The probe binds specifically to its complementary RNA sequence on the membrane, allowing the detection and visualization of the target RNA molecule.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DNA: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA molecules.

Option C - Proteins: Western blotting, immunohistochemistry, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) are commonly used for protein detection and analysis.

Option D - None: Northern blotting is specifically used for the detection of RNA molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following investigative procedures does not require the use of real-time PCR to determine viral load?

choices.text: Person with hepatitis B on tenofovir therapy
Detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis
BK virus in patient of allograft renal transplant
CMV in patient of liver transplant

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Detection of HSV Causing Temporal Encephalitis:

  • Real-time PCR is used for the quantification, hence real-time PCR is not preferred for detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis, instead conventional PCR is preferred for the detection of the HSV DNA in cerebrospinal fluid. It can also differentiate between HSV 1 and HSV 2. Monitoring viral load is not routinely performed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Person with Hepatitis B on Tenofovir Therapy: In individuals with hepatitis B receiving tenofovir therapy, monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR is essential. It helps determine the response to treatment, assess viral suppression, and evaluate the risk of drug resistance.

Option C - BK Virus in a Patient with Allograft Renal Transplant: BK virus infection can occur in patients who have undergone renal transplantation. Monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR in urine or blood samples is important to detect and manage BK virus-associated complications, such as nephropathy. 

Option D - CMV in a Patient with Liver Transplant: Cytomegalovirus infection is a significant concern in patients undergone solid organ transplantation. Real-time PCR for CMV viral load in blood is commonly performed in these patients to monitor for active infection, guide antiviral therapy, and assess response to treatment.
